movie_review_blurb: An often amusing reimagining of Bronze Age history  that, while it doesn't quite match the best of Aardman, is still solid family entertainment.
Overall, a superior sequel.
An interesting introduction to (or reminder of) Amanda Knox's story following the murder of her flatmate Meredith Kercher, but it doesn't have the depth of other recent true-crime investigations.
The story of Britpop's iconic band at its peak is told with wit, honesty and swagger. Which, given its two leads, is entirely fitting.
When location scouting is the most striking aspect of a film, something's awry. And sadly this mystery fails to intrigue.
Effectively scary and occasionally inventive, Blair Witch is a solid genre film both helped and hindered by its franchise's place in cinematic history.

Passable for the most part, but laughably inept in places, Ben-Hur 2016 relies on its overly CG action to pull it through. But in the end it can only stagger, bruised and bloodied, across the finish line.
Yet another success for stop-motion giants Laika, Kubo boasts big laughs and effective scares in a typically gorgeous animated tale.
An affable adventure with a strong voice cast. What it lacks in originality, it claws back with strong visual gags and a witty script.
Witty and moving, this is a low-budget Brit triumph that marks its director as a talent to watch.
An adaptation of the Dave Eggers novel that struggles to make itself stand out, content instead to coast by on gentle comedy and Hanks' charm. Pleasant but ultimately forgettable.
A perfectly pitched blast of nostalgia, which will transport you to that time in life when the future stretched before you and anything seemed possible.
Light on plot, high on braindead action, it turns out there's a reason hardly any films are shot in first-person view - it's just not a very good idea.
It has its moments, but it blows the interesting premise - the resurrection of Jesus told as a mystery - too early for an overlong, overly religious finale.
A thriller that winds you tighter and tighter before its secrets come tumbling out in a cathartic finale.
A fun, if patchy, alternative to the glut of 'the world is about to end unless we do something' comic-book films.
A highly quotable, visual treat that's packed with in-jokes but is entertaining enough on its own terms to work for fans and non-fans alike. The best Batman film in years.
An interesting premise fails to ignite amid an underwritten central romance and some clichéd plotting. An often eye-rolling ride.
An effectively spooky opening gives way to a film that's fun, funny and full of energy.
Part Alien, part Gravity, just not as good as either of them. But Life whips along at a decent pace and deploys enough engaging action sequences to make it work.
With great performances across the board and a socially relevant story, Mudbound will resonate long after the credits roll.
Brawl In Cell Block 99 takes its time with its set-up, but that only makes the action that follows all the more effective. And Vaughn as an action hero works surprisingly well.
A case of a missed opportunity. It references all the right films, but The Snowman comes off as a pale imitation.
Two compelling leads and a mix of adventure and romance. It's a pleasant experience, if not one that will linger long in the memory.
Brutal in its depictions of violence, Brimstone is tough to watch at times, but never less than gripping, even as the clock creeps up to the 150-minute mark.
A witty and touching father-son tale. And at its centre: a startling debut from Will Tilston, whose compelling performance ensures its emotional moments land successfully.
This is an uneven adventure that's saved by the spectacle of its towering title character and the various beasts with whom he shares his island home.

A sports film with an arthouse sensibility. It benefits greatly from its chosen subject matter - two of the most remarkable characters in sporting history - but only manages to truly get under the skin of one of them.
There are 15 more Mitch Rapp books, but a sequel feels unlikely.
A great cast is let down by a script that fails to provide a compelling mystery to solve. Never mind as a big-screen production, this would be disappointing as a BBC mini-series.
The third Despicable Me film chronologically is also the third-best in terms of quality. But it has just enough energy and flashes of inspiration to suggest it's a franchise that could run and run.
A fascinating but flawed portrait of a fascinating but flawed man. However, with Cox so good, it's a surprise Churchill isn't being held back until awards season.
A confused comedy that wastes the promise of its premise. And Brad Pitt's performance, sadly, belongs in a different film entirely.
Scuppered by a lazy script that fails to effectively build tension, Unforgettable lives up to its name, but not for the right reasons.
Fails to capitalise on its good intentions to subvert and modernise the franchise.
Set nearly half a century ago, but remarkably prescient in these "fake news" times, The Post is an engaging and masterfully acted tale sure to be in the running come the Oscars.
Complex, poised and beguilingly earthy. Stephane Brizé's decade-spanning epic is a sensitively performed, memorably fragmentary look at one woman undone by the feckless men in her life.
From a purely technical perspective, Life hits the market standard for impressive effects work across the board. However, its narrative can't keep pace.

The very anarchic spirit Black's Dewey Finn imparts on the youngsters falls away in an avalanche of tidy sentiment and warm fuzzies, and it becomes clearer than in the Farrelly Brothers' 'Shallow Hal' that he's at sea when he's forced to dial down his per

... So bad that it rockets through the gauntlet of insipidity and tastelessness and emerges on the other side to become good, only to ricochet off the wall of cinematic decency and become bad all over again.
At best a spotty spy spoof with little to say about the genre beyond what Mike Myers already accomplished in 'Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery' (and wrecked in its two dreadful sequels).

Even a comedy that prides itself on the crudity of its sexual pranks can find a kernel honesty among the bathroom humor - and even the most insufferably crass, libidinously inflamed, knuckle-dragging mook has a heart in there somewhere. (Even Stifler.) A
... Dumb, lazy, predictable and usually preposterous. Occasionally it's fun, but that's no excuse.
A lightweight but occasionally clever comedy that surprisingly treats its premise as more than a punch line - and does it with a big heart.
'Grind' rather economically describes the experience for anyone above age 11 who wanders into this skateboarding 'Rad' retread for 'jackass' fans.
Applying 'criticism' to 'Freddy vs. Jason' isn't just tedious - it's pointless.

What eventually keeps Laura Hillenbrand's rousing true tale of the downtrodden horse that blossomed into a spectacular champion from galloping into the winner's circle on screen is its writer-director's maddening insistence that we be edified and inspired
Victor Salva's laziness is explicable by slasher-film standards, but still infuriating.
Not as disposable as we first think, and ultimately watchable once we get past an hour that's only marginally less damaging than a 'Diff'rent Strokes' marathon - but it's not exactly inspired either.
With sound and fury, Robert Rodriguez is purely, simply having fun making movies. Leave logic at the door ...
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Man, Kate Beckinsale looks great in tight leather.I mention this not because I'm so very lonely, but because it's the only reward for enduring the oppressive gloom of 'Underworld.'
Where McCanlies eventually almost succeeds in demolishing his laid-back little embassy of wonder and good will is his refusal to practice what his characters preach.
A thriller as tedious as 'Cold Creek Manor' benefits from a 'glass is half-full' philosophy: Each minute we spend in unspeakable boredom means we're one minute closer to the end.
I've been placing all my money on Vin Diesel, but it's time to hedge my bets: The Rock is the action star for this generation.

... An inspired black comedy sharing the same roof with a vile, mean-spirited revenge melodrama. Like its bewildered landlords saddled with an impossible tenant, these two unwitting roommates co-habitate uneasily at best.

Urination can be funny. So can severed ears, folliculitis, rock-climbing trophy wives, chest self-exams and owls that drink from the toilet. Occasionally, even a massive head wound can be funny. None of these things are funny in 'My Boss's Daughter.'

We find a few unexpected treasures mildewing away in Jerry Bruckheimer's chest of slimy old clichés: a script that occasionally borders on cleverness, a winningly sleazy performance by Johnny Depp and a considerable sense of style from Gore Verbinski.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Like the fun drunk who loses all his friends when he lapses into self-loathing, the edgy spirit of anarchy in 'Anger Management' gets beaten into submission when it develops a conscience.
Among the minefield of paradoxes and contradictions in 'Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines,' one strikes with deadly accuracy: This is a summer sequel Stanley Kubrick would have loved.

If you're amused by watching Vin Diesel rough up bad guys in loud, frenetic, blood-soaked action thrillers, you'll be the first one in line. If you're not, no level of critical adulation could entice you.

Without Denzel Washington's charm - the cocked head, the sly, toothy grin and eyes that scream 'trust me' - a thriller as lame and preposterous as 'Out of Time' would just sink back into the lethargic swamp of sweat-soaked neo-noir that seems to seep in e
It's so bad there's no way it can't attract a cult following.

Should sheer boredom or an advanced state of masochism compel you to see the film, try this instead: Take seven $1 bills and methodi-cally shred them into pieces of equal size. You'll end up with an expensive bowl of green confetti - and an infinitely mor

Kids aren't dumb. They have opinions, hopes and dreams that deserve to be recognized and exercised, and cinema should be an engaging experience full of power and potential - not a babysitter. 'Holes' is not a babysitter.
One of those rare superior sequels - a dark, often exhilarating and occasionally even thoughtful improvement on its portable plastic predecessor.
If you fit into its target demographic, 'The Lizzie McGuire Movie' is inoffensive fluff. If your age surpasses your shoe size, you're better off re-grouting your tile.

I'm not offended by its singular lack of energy or invention - I never expected more than a cinematic Big Mac when I saw Eddie Mur-phy's name above the title 'Daddy Day Care.' But what I got was a sandwich from a gas station.

This DreamWorks animated outing eventually surrenders to the paralyzing goop and arthritic formula that haunt 90 percent of the features churned out by arch-rival The Mouse House - but somehow fills its sails with enough wit and wonder to stay afloat.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Hopefully November's release of 'Revolutions' will reveal a clarity of purpose and a satisfying end to the saga. In mid-May, I can only go by what I see on the screen. And it's a muddled, overreaching, occasionally engrossing mess.

As if running low on dramatic irony, Jim Carrey and his just-add-water team of merry pranksters from 'Ace Ventura: Pet Detective' and 'Liar Liar' come armed with a premise as heavenly as they come - and aim for sea level.

A superior entry in the exhausting oeuvre of genre classics given a slick spit-and-polish for the next generation (think 'Ocean's Eleven') - if that's your bag, shift your brain into first (but not neutral) and enjoy.
The peerless partnership of Disney and Pixar is officially five-for-five.

... The quintessence of the mainstream summer sequel: loud, slick, preposterous and thoroughly disposable, where any potentially damaging sugar of invention is quickly, safely flushed out of its engine so the machinery of manipulation and the Law of Dimin
Why, Lord, why?
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As in last winter's unfairly overlooked 'Dark Blue,' Ron Shelton lures us into his underground lair with genre clichés only to sucker-punch us with something unexpected.

Here's the good news: After months of intense tinkering and desperate repair, 'Hulk' no longer looks like Gumby on steroids. Here's the bad news: It may be the most singularly confused comic book adaptation ever to reach the silver screen.
It's loud, energetic and popping with enough eye candy to induce pancreatic shock in a sperm whale - and the best part? It has absolutely no plot.
This set of 'In-Laws' are stuck with each other -- but we have a choice. The right one opened in 1979.

A brash, bloody and simply exhilarating revenge melodrama and stylistic indulgence inspired by an imagination that spent thousands of hours absorbing pulp paperbacks, comic books, 'Kung Fu,' the mythology of Bruce Lee and Hong Kong chop-socky epics while
Tim Burton constructs an eye-popping, kaleidoscopic landscape of sound, fury and fantasy -- and remembers to make a movie to go with it.
... bores its way in and lingers for hours, even days before we finally can come to terms with it - and ourselves. But the less we know, the more we understand.
Yet another sleeper hit becomes a cynical franchise. I guess 'Nappy-Cutz' wins after all.
As Barrymore reminds us: Nothing beats a first kiss. Who would have thought an Adam Sandler vehicle in February would be the first romantic comedy in years to mean it?
... Nothing if not fluffy -- but oddly, egregiously offensive in ways far more insidious and damaging than merely wasting our time.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: ... limp and dreadfully dull.
Emerging from the Job-like endurance test of this film's unrelenting horror, it's impossible not to be moved by its visceral impact ...
With Ashley Judd above the title, no cookie-cutter contrivance is unaccounted for, no performance betraying the hint of any effort beyond showing up on the set.
Something we seldom expect (or get) in the creatively bankrupt trend of adapting moldy old TV shows for the big screen: funny.
I cried 'Please, Lord, make it stop' at about the 90-minute mark -- long after I was numbed into a vegetative state by reheated spy cliches and sub-sophomoric bathroom jokes.
... a mean, nasty, mostly laughless 104 minutes spent in dogged pursuit of an ironic cause that's as subtle as a falling gargoyle's head.
A remake as soulless as the hordes of undead that attack with maddening persistence.
Why keep the 'Walking Tall' brand name at all? The juke-joint mama doesn't even take a bullet beneath her beehive this time around.
... the true star of this film is Eduardo Serra, who should have had the Oscar. Sweeping fantasy vistas are easy; creating a sensual feast through the camera's lens is hard.
Before the opening credits had ended, I was counting down the minutes until I could get back to scraping old tile adhesive off my kitchen floor.
Hancock keeps what could have been a leaden behemoth accessible and engaging by drawing a bead on the personalities of the men who've loomed over history books, warts and all.
Whoever first had the big idea of revisiting this material should be hung up by his Buster Browns and forced to watch the result -- then he'll know what 'punishment' means.
With every caption dancing across the screen to overstate the obvious, it plays like a feature-length PSA for thetruth.com - only this time, the drug is kidnapping.
It exhilarates even as it maddens.
Theron doesn't 'play' Wuornos as much as inhabit her - with pity, volcanic anger, confusion, occasional euphoria and mostly, impenetrable sadness.
Mountain Dew is not a suggestion for your choice of movie-time beverage. It's a mandate.
...if this film were independently produced and released only on the art-house circuit critics would be knifing each other for a chance to praise its 'haunting power.'
... The ninth circle of gearhead Hell.

... a curious form of cinematic matricide worthy of kabuki drama is being committed here - the offspring is rising up to disembowel its celluloid parent, visiting cruel punishment on Tobe Hooper for the unforeseeable sins that have sprung from the genre h
I never thought I'd find myself waxing nostalgic for the charms of 'Scary Movie 2.'
Keanu Reeves improves marginally over his laughably stone-faced slog through "Reloaded" - his emotional range upgrades from a spatula to at least that of a lint brush ...
Saddle our freshly hirsute hero with an insufferably chatty-cute sidekick ... and you're pouring chocolate sauce on a Double Stuf Oreo.
... a shrill, soulless and disturbing void of imagination that murders the spirit of a beloved children's book -- which the filmmakers obviously have not read.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Works on a human scale of epic proportions while delivering a ripping, full-bodied sea adventure that gives its audience enough credit to connect the dots.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Peppered with so many moments of raw, affecting honesty that it's intensely difficult to dislike -- and tempting to forgive Richard Curtis for not finishing what he starts,
With Ferrell's charm, this knowing wink to the Yuletide fuzzies of yore survives the saccharine assault that claims most "family" films released between Nov. 1 and Christmas.
The barbecue sandwich I had for lunch was infinitely more memorable than the movie that preceded it.
Eddie Murphy has been many things to many people in his tempestuous career. Until now, 'mayo-and-bologna-on-white' hasn't been one of them.
When we know someone and love them -- that's when we can laugh at them. If Peter and Bobby Farrelly get it, anybody can.
Jack gets away with playing Jack ... because who else does it better? But it's Keaton who keeps their chemistry firing on all cylinders.
'The Lord of the Rings" saga ends as it began -- with elegant simplicity and heart.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: ... a good epic that tries too hard to be great.
... the latest corpse in a long string of casualties left by Ben Affleck's 'star power' and credibility void as a man of action.
In all its harrowing witlessness, it ironically proves the healing power of laughter.
Proof that Joel Schumacher is at his best with a simple story and a small budget.
Not a SCANDALOUS waste of cinematic resources -- just another limp, uninspired romantic comedy that wastes the talents of its stellar cast.
Ron Howard's answer to 'The Searchers' is a tone poem -- whose tone has gone disastrously, horribly wrong.
A dumb, insanely predictable apocalyptic thriller that somehow manages to be enormously entertaining.
Another of the three or four obnoxious, race-baiting flops Hollywood routinely seems to tolerate from Martin Lawrence between can't-miss blockbusters such as "Big Momma's House" and "Bad Boys."
It's understandable why it sat on the shelf for almost two years. What I can't comprehend is why it didn't stay there.
'You can't handle Steve Irwin in anything more than half-hour increments. At 90 minutes, I was hoping a giant reptile would gobble me up and put me out of my misery.'
'... So waterlogged by cliches not even the effortless authority of Harrison Ford or the carefully inflected sympathy of Liam Neeson can keep it afloat.'
The B-movie is back in business and it's here to stay.
'A fresh-faced, big-hearted and frequently funny thrill ride for the kiddies, with enough eye candy and cheeky wit to keep parents away from the concession stand.'
The video companion for 'The Complete Idiot's Guide to Movie Sequels.'
... The cinematic equivalent of the 8-year-old hooligan who mocks you by repeating everything you say.
A cleverly constructed and surprisingly soul-searching suspense thriller from a screen icon who's begun to contemplate his own mortality.
The 'Top Gun' of its era: loud, overproduced, ultraslick and sorely lacking in such nuisances as complex characterizations, compelling antagonists or the element of surprise.
I found a rare moment when I couldn't predict where it was headed, but John Stockwell directs at such a breezy clip and the surfing shots are so galvanizing, I didn't mind.
A scandalous waste of cinematic resources: a comedy with no laughs, a sci-fi epic without wonder, an action thriller with no thrills.
This mind-numbing comic void never generates enough electricity to brown an English muffin.
Exactly what its title implies: lusty, boisterous and utterly charming.
Taken purely as an exercise in style, this oppressively gloomy techno-horror clambake is impossible to ignore. But as a movie, it's a humorless, disjointed mess.
No surprise ever threatens to surface in this unintentionally hilarious 'Play Misty for Me' with mononucleosis.
... After 90 minutes of mind-numbing explosions, I cheered when a death by electrocution finally broke the monotony.
Whether the film 'works' is a question in direct correlation to willingness to set aside preconceptions of logic, characterization or ambition - and tolerance of Tom Green.
With Witherspoon's charisma and the infectious efforts of a supporting cast, it's hard not to like this trifling little stroll down memory lane - but not impossible.
Sam Mendes murders the sophomore jinx in this sumptuously melancholic realization of Richard Piers Rayner and Max Allan Collins' graphic novel.
'Jack Black is back on track.'
'An admittedly raunchy but smart satirical poke at sexual politics in the information age. It's also funnier than we have any right to expect.'
'A flawed gem of darkly comic luster.'
Managed to win me over with delicious pith, irresistible warmth and charm to burn

"The Prince of Magnolias Floats on a Fried Green American Quilt" ... a big ol' crawfish boil of Southern-fried sentimentality that throws every imaginable chick-flick cliché into the pot and heats to a healthy simmer.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Is Ben Affleck such an indispensable talent -- or box-office draw -- that his presence is worth wrecking an entire film franchise to accomodate his youth?
'Undercover Brother' comes packed with possibilities, but can't keep its groove thing shaking with enough consistency to be any more than a 'Saturday Night Live' sketch that goes on too long.
What Lucas needs to wrap up this franchise properly is a return to the fundamentals: less overplotted hooey, more thick blue liquid.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: ... Raimi delivers a first-rate entertainment for the summer crowd, slick as an extra-large popcorn with butter - and about as substantial - when he has all the ingredients for a truly exhilarating experience with a life beyond the multiplex.
... a haunting, relentlessly disturbing film in the pure Southern Gothic tradition.
Sinfully tasteless cinema was everywhere in 2001 - but this movie is so bad it's Freudian.
We shouldn't expect a triumphal moment in modern American cinema when we see Jackie Chan and Jennifer Love Hewitt above a title - and we don't get it.
... works solely on the power of its lead performances and a script that manages to stay smart, in spite of its director's mouth-breathing clamor to film a Harlequin novel.
Producer Sean S. Cunningham and cronies have wisely given up trying to scare us with this series.
What's refreshing about 'Joshua' is its acknowledgment that a spiritual 'message' can permeate without constant reminders of 'Look alive out there - here comes a Sunday school lesson!'
... a savory sip of cognac in a Pabst Blue Ribbon summer of overbaked fantasy franchises and witless popcorn thrillers.
A feature-length in joke that has marvelous fun with the decades of homoerotic and reefer-smoking subtexts assigned to it by people with entirely too much time on their hands.
Some Like It Hot on the Hardwood proves once again that a man in drag is not in and of himself funny.

I still can't surmise what possible appeal the football-headed crusader and his neighborhood gang might have for anyone who's evolved beyond primordial ooze.
'The once-dynamic duo of Tommy Lee Jones and Will Smith phones it in - and a by-the-numbers script all but hands them the receiver.'
A dumb, mean-spirited movie based on a dumb, mean-spirited video game.
Thekids will probably stay amused at the kaleidoscope of big, colorful characters. Mom and Dad can catch some quality naptime along the way.
Every time Hopkins spills out a lofty intellectual portent or serves up a defiant sneer, we can hear the faint 'ka-ching!' in his agent's office.
One of those films that has us choking back a derisive howl at all its platitudes about 'honesty' - because an honest moment is impossible to find.
The respective charms of Sandra Bullock and Hugh Grant have worn threadbare.
To use the obvious metaphor and equate 'Envy' to what Jack Black's miracle product is designed to clean up would be an insult to the canine digestive system.

If the only moments worth remembering are fleeting glimpses of 1967, why bother? Because Disney wants your dollars, that's why - and your only alternative at the multiplex this season is 'Kangaroo Jack.'
The greatest living American filmmaker returns to form in a triumph of raw cinematic power.
Kurt Russell delivers the goods with astonishing simplicity and understated power.

Don't be bamboozled by the humanist mythopoetic title: 'Tears of the Sun' is 'Rambo' with a better script and a sense of style.

I never expected 'Willard'" to be a page-marker in modern cinema. All I had hoped was that it wouldn't lose its taste for good baloney be-fore I did. We already had the cheese.

No better or worse than 'Truth or Consequences, N.M.' or any other interchangeable actioner with imbecilic Mafia toolbags botching a routine assignment in a Western backwater.
Easily the most manipulative thriller since Brian De Palma retired to a career of spectacular irrelevance. That's why it's so effective - and fiendishly satisfying.

Paul Thomas Anderson's surreal, frightening, self-indulgent masterpiece.
When a hail of buddy-comedy clichés works in service of two stars as appealing as Murphy and Wilson, memories of 'The Beverly Hillbillies' can wash away like cinematic Calgon.
Even if it's just a narrative bridge, this second series installment is still a glorious reward for those who paid attention last time.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The industrial-strength artifice and bogus sentiment that fueled 1994's inexplicable megahit 'The Santa Clause' returns for another ride in Santa's souped-up sleigh.
Pierce Brosnan was born to play James Bond, but he'll never make the role his own if an intelligent script doesn't pass through his mail slot soon.
Manipulation has no learning curve.
Not as much a remake of a sci-fi classic as a reverent interpretation by a filmmaker at peace with his material.
Wes Craven's presence is felt; not the Craven of 'A Nightmare on Elm Street' or 'The Hills Have Eyes,' but the sad schlock merchant of 'Deadly Friend.'
Where the first film was the exposition, the follow-up is the reward - taking our heroes on a darker, more rewarding journey as we watch them deepen and mature with time.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: If De Niro wants to wind down his career as the McDonald's of master thespians, we can't stop him. But those of us who've tasted crème brulée will still know the difference.
If you've spent every waking moment since the summer of 1991 pining for a 'New Jack City' with a salsa soundtrack, your cinematic savior has arrived.

Not as consistently funny as 'Heathers' or corrosive as 'Election,' but usually hilarious and occasionally chilling in its observations of 'Girl World.'
A great comedy filmmaker knows great comedy needn't always make us laugh. Tim Story's not there yet - but 'Barbershop' shows he's on his way.

No level of noble intent by the filmmakers can compel me to recommend a work of cinema that's this cheap, simplistic and sloppy.

Utterly joyless - although you can somehow imagine Nigel Farage enjoying it immensely.
Manakamana is a travel film that's not about the ride, but the riders. Ourselves included, of course.
Shot in atmospheric, grainy 'Scope by Erik Wilson, this elegant study looks less like a documentary than like a highly staged thriller, a piece of brooding provincial noir.
A teasing essay on sibling tensions ... a backdrop for a gonzo self-portrait, a likeably self-deprecating music-biz counterpart to Louis C.K.'s TV shows.
It is a film that maintains its illusion with grace-and ruefully unmasks that illusion every bit as gracefully.
First-time writer-director Batra nearly overplays his hand at a couple of moments, but all in all this is a film of finely judged reserve, and acutely anti-sentimental.
A shapeless mess.
Pawel Pawlikowski's Ida is a remarkably beautiful film.
It's an informative film, rich in ideas because LeWitt's ideas are rich, but it didn't make me curious either to see more of his work or know more about this oddly nebulous figure.
A touch slapdash, repetitive, indulgent, and yet compelling, mainly because its subject is so troublingly, excessively odd.
Mr. Turner works at once as a warts-and-all portrait of the painter and his circle, and as a large-scale evocation of Victorian England.
A complex and teasing drama that mixes together paedophile abduction, video surveillance, enigmatic femmes fatales and Mozart's The Magic Flute.
Glazer has worked an extended thread of extremely earthbound vérité footage into a film that tells the most outré intergalactic story.
This is a clipped, fragmented piece of cinematic modernism, shuffling its time frames in a staccato narrative that makes for a tense, involving experience from start to finish.
Goodbye To Language follows in the eye-searing, mind-spinning wake of Godard's recent features, taking the fragmentation even further than in his Film Socialisme.
Because Edge of Tomorrow is effectively about the infinite refloggability of cinematic horses, it manages to break the chain of formulaic repetition and come out surprisingly fresh.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's an icky affair: more Perry (Katy) than Perrault (Charles).
Polanski has given Seigner a gift of a part: she's brazen, energetic and extremely funny in an ultimately scary way.

Something sparks thanks to Jim Norton's robust but nuanced performance as the cantankerous, obsessive hardliner Father Sheridan, whom he brings to life with terrifying fire and not a little caustic humour.
This is a subtle political film: one that fully dramatises a situation and lets us think out its contradictions for ourselves.
It's essentially Blazing Saddles, only the fart jokes aren't quite as fresh.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Any thought of Diaz as a director who makes it all up as he goes along is comprehensively belied by a tightly structured narrative that, for all its length and languid pacing, contains very little dead time.
The message is so important - and Rasoulof is conveying it under such difficult conditions - that the film rather transcends normal considerations.
A genuinely spectacular project that has the imaginative and philosophical dimensions that most blockbusters would never dream of venturing into.
Night Moves stages an intelligent debate on activism, radicalism and ethics, but most importantly, it makes the people who perform militant acts very human and very knowable...
[I]t was a thrill to discover something so bold, innovative, and downright wayward.
[T]here's a sometimes doggedly to-the-point quality to the film that you can't help admiring in contrast to the breathlessness of so much CGI cinema.
[A]n atmospheric, elegant piece, a more delicate, intriguingly nervous piece of pulp noir.
A disappointing film that loses dramatic momentum after an arrestingly grim first act.
Extra-terrible, more like.
As the film veers wildly from poised badinage to skullduggery to florid melodrama, a little chaos isn't the half of it.
As for Shia, he's wildly self-indulgent and narcissistic: all puppy eyes, emoting and angsting like there's no tomorrow. He just doesn't know when eneouf is eneouf.
Million Dollar Baby is as close to an anti-Rocky as a sports picture ever came, but even when following familiar paths, it stakes out its own distinctively harsh territory.
My Friend Victoria offers a ruefully witty auto-critique of the limitations of bourgeois French cinema, which either cannot see other races or absorbs them till they disappear
Honoré's film aspires to be inclusive, even encyclopedic-through myth, to speak about the whole of the human condition today as Ovid spoke about it in his time.
Wwithout a doubt, it's seductively perplexing and devilishly good-looking -- and if you like it, you'll probably find that one viewing isn't enough.

Michael Gioulakis's cinematography, more art-house than genre with its eerie pools of light at night, brings an arrestingly static, tableau-like quality that echoes the highly staged scenarios of Gregory Crewdson's photos.

There's a certain breezy obviousness to much of the humor: it's like a broad, sitcom expansion of a Moral Tale or a Comedies and Proverbs episode that Baumbach's beloved Eric Rohmer might have made on a sortie to Williamsburg.
All in all, a quietly magical piece of cinema, a mind-bender of the subtlest kind.
An almost zen-like exercise in wholesale slaughter as abstraction.

The argument for Cobain's brilliance never quite convinces until towards the end, with his MTV Unplugged performance, in which a whole new compelling register to his talent emerges - too late for the film, and alas, for the singer himself.
The hard-bitten terseness doesn't stop a faint glimmer of sentiment leaking in, but Hopkins is a stylist and a social observer with a cogent personal signature.
It's presumably a labour of love, yet it doesn't give you any sense of a personality or imagination behind the camera.
It's nice to see the always compelling Hawke - here, tenser and more laconic than ever - in a role where his face's deep stress lines come into their own.
The term used by one commentator is "militainment", which is about as ugly - and as chilling - a neologism as you're ever likely to hear.

It won't do the film any harm at the box office that Helen Mirren twinkles indomitably. She's as good as ever, but really - of all the things you want to see Dame Helen doing indomitably, twinkling isn't among them.
I can't help feeling the film is ultimately hollow.

The acting is impeccably controlled, with leads Kuhnke and Kongsli sympathetically establishing the genteel, only slightly self-satisfied blandness of their characters, then tracing the cracks that spread in their makeup.
Hsiao-Kang's bad night out is one of the things that marks Rebels as a Tsai Ming-liang film. There's never any real, safe home in his films.
It never transcends reverent pastiche, down to the hackneyed twang of Morricone-style guitars.
It's a good-humoured, no-frills story of a Welsh working-class community that clubbed together to invest in a thoroughbred, and ended up with the winner of the Welsh Grand National.

It's a film to bring tears to the eyes of a cynic - in fact, a cynic might relish it more than anyone, since it's the counterpointing of exuberance with unashamed bleakness that makes The Last Five Years so rich.
With its small-town atmospherics, a juicy supporting cast of character players, plus Addison Timlin's personable, plucky "final girl", this Town is pulled off with polished, enjoyable brashness ...
Gerard Barrett's second feature isn't short of integrity, but it's hampered by solemnity and - even for this school of hard-times realism - a somewhat puritanical refusal of visual appeal.
Hardy is very odd, as usual.
Iris is a fond portrait of a personality who could easily be regarded as a freakshow. Better, though, to say that she's an entertainer.
But to expand Camus's slender story to 101 minutes, Oelhoffen decides to say a lot more than the basic dramatic situation necessarily demands.
Reality seems so nonchalant about its somewhat mechanical strangeness that the effect is not so much "WTF?", more "where-exactly-are-you-going-with-this?"

André Téchiné is a past master at creating narratively complex films that have the stimulating density of novels, and page-turners at that. When it comes to true crime, however... he's on less firm terrain.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mon Roi's melodrama glossiness grates more than it convinces.

A bold, evocative film, in which voices, intonations and noises off - and a terrific unseen supporting cast - build up a detailed picture of a world and a man's life, as elegantly and economically as the best radio play.
Pacino's buoyant self-mockery goes a long way towards redeeming the actor, who's on genial and winning form.

There's irony but no cruelty here; Rohmer is not making Louise the butt of the joke or saying "serve her right." It's simply in the nature of stories illustrating a proverb that someone is bound to suffer from the principle at stake.
movie_title: Les Nuits de la pleine lune (Full Moon in Paris) (1984)

movie_review_blurb: Stylistically, The Duke of Burgundy is an aesthete's dream - meticulously refined, delicate as a fritillary's wing.
Loznitsa offers something that these days is rare and precious: close-up coverage of history in the making that doesn't have "breaking news" ribbons or network logos plastered all over it.

By the time the mind-bending paradoxes kick in, the film's potential complexities have devolved into mere clutter, both narrative and visual: the coolest thing the device does is to make debris revolve in mid-air.
There's plenty of subtly handled excess to hold you aghast-and whichever way you slice, I maintain that yes, it is the damnedest sports movie you've ever seen.
[A] confident and provocative piece that, as I'm hardly the first critic to point out, you should think twice about choosing as a date movie.
It's a no-nonsense, old-school exercise, with a tinge of borderline trashiness.
The sheer assaultive power of Goodbye to Language makes it Godard's most vibrant and exciting film for some time and, you might say, his most terroristic.
[O]nce our explorers pass into another galaxy...things take on a new dimension of banality and the film, however magnificently conceived in visual terms, becomes just another space adventure.

Amirpour's film feels like an elaborately punkish code-scrambling gesture rather than a fully formed organic statement, but that doesn't matter-it has style, grace, and imagination, and as artistic gestures go, could hardly be more devil-may-care.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Babadook is a film that Val Lewton and Jacques Tourneur, screen horror's high priests of the unseen, would approve of.
Winter Sleep is without doubt a formidably achieved, intellectually substantial drama that deals variously with questions of conscience, responsibility and self-deception.
It's an impressive, substantial piece of work, and a proper old-fashioned nail-biter too.
The film's exuberance, and the sense that it's all one big gimmick-packed action toy, give Hellboy II: The Golden Army a refreshing cinematic purity.
For the most part, however, the comedy feels forced, as if Bozon is indulging a rather obscure private joke.
Maybe we should suspend the reductive question, "Is it any good or not?" and acknowledge that it's a fascinating, tantalising film that will continue to be argued about.

Marshall delivers Into the Woods to the screen dutifully, but what's lost is the real point of the show as an exploration of storytelling-& the playfulness too, in both senses, for stage Sondheim is both ludic & fully mindful of its own status as play.
A perspicaciously empathetic study of solitude, depression and anxiety.
What remains is by no means catastrophic, just solemn and inconclusive, with the darker psychological resonances (Cage's character faces encroaching dementia) lost in a rather woolly mix.
A respectably effective, decorously English addition to the current ghost story wave - Frightfully Insidious, as it were.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Enemy has morbid elegance to spare, which should guarantee it some long-term cult prestige.
A square-jawed, furrowed-browed, altogether joyless film, with a hero to match ...
This quietly magnificent piece should put the Zellners on the map: one day, the Coens will make movies inspired by them.
You hope for the tang of lemon drizzle; what you ultimately get is Madeira, with the proverbial soggy bottom.
The film leaps into a dizzy abyss of temporal paradoxes, made all the dizzier by its transgender premise - a modern Tiresias myth plaited into a Möbius strip.
Retro but totally modern, frivolous yet fundamentally serious, The Artist is a thing of grace and joy and a great American film -- of the sort it takes the French to make.
The film delivers an intriguing slant on rural-peril convention, even if it never completely remaps the old weird territory.
Only in spurts does the film achieve an outre flavour of pop Gogol.

Hard to Be a God is such a singular anomaly that it's tempting to suspend any value judgment. I felt as much overwhelmed, oppressed, exhausted by it as bewitched, and I wonder how many viewers its genuinely hermetic brilliance will connect with.
But what makes Gangs one of the rare recent Indian mainstream movies to achieve crossover exposure is the way that it intersects with and echoes other international variants on gangster themes.
Prolific Quebecqois film-maker Denis Côté explores the world of work in Joy Of Man's Desiring (Que ta joie demeure), a poetic and hybrid study of industrial life, factories and the meaning of labour.
When Evening Falls is intriguing as the latest intervention in cinema's long debate on itself, but non-specialists will find it a little arid.
movie_title: When Evening Falls on Bucharest or Metabolism (2015)

movie_review_blurb: One of the outstanding films of 2014, Leviathan lives up to its title: it's a behemoth of intelligent contemporary cinema.
Birdman has wings, for certain, even if you find the feathers sticking in your throat now and then.
Redmayne's quietly exuberant performance is admirable and engaging, never over-stressing its tour de force dimension. But the real colour is brought by Felicity Jones as Jane ...
The Duke of Burgundy is a deeply eccentric filigree of a film, as aesthetically refined a piece of cinematic artifice as I've seen in ages.
We Are the Best! is a low-key pleasure. It is perhaps not a project that tests Moodysson as a director but it resoundingly shows his brilliance at directing young performers.
An exemplary piece of journalism...
Gleeson's magnificent intensity and the palpable wit and intelligence of the film's conception make Calvary an audacious advance on The Guard.

The humour gets weirder as it goes on and it's among the lightest of Pixar's films, but the first 20 minutes offer the saddest, most poignant sequence seen in an animation film since Bambi's mother died.
Admirers of the Coens - including those who have lapsed, like myself - will rejoice in their best film for a long while, and one of their most irreducibly oddball.
Peli's film revives the honourable tradition of chills-by-suggestion, whereby what we don't see is far scarier than what we do.
The visual panache is pleasingly crackpot, but that's about as far as the film goes.
It doesn't say anything too deep, but it says it with crystalline style.
The film has a warm, lived-in period feel close to Woody Allen's Bullets Over Broadway, and a similar ain't-theatre-crazy vibe. But there's a hard-bitten realism behind the sweetness.

Avatar is a phenomenon you can't ignore, monumentally imposing and done with extraordinary expertise - but the same could be said of the Dubai skyline, and I'm not sure that represents any future worth investing in.

While it feels slapdash rather than properly punk-collage ragged, Sex & Drugs & Rock & Roll is an honest job, and it makes a good case for including Dury's work and personality in any Brit-culture list of Reasons to be Cheerful.
A horribly credible, chillingly beautiful and wholly uncompromising drama. It's the end of the world, all right, but no one feels in the least bit fine.
Soft, warm, doughy comfort food it was no doubt intended to be. The screenplay is jovial; the actors twinkle and Mamma Mia! fans should love it.
It excels as a courtroom drama, a tense thriller, a ringing call to arms, and, most of all, as a humbling portrait of the unflappable, indefatigable farmers and their families.

This low-budget British chamber piece has an intriguing scenario, so it's a shame that the po-faced, sci-fi-tinged screenplay fixates on the applicants' efforts to detect invisible ink on their exam papers.
This provocative and involving piece proves that the French tradition of intelligent, adult film-making is still healthy.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Not only is this a rare Hollywood production that offers as much substance and panache as the cream of current US TV, I'd go further and say its cynical wit almost places it in the Billy Wilder bracket.
A long, impressively clever sketch that gets hung up on being a sweet-and-sour romcom.
Precious is part pamphlet, part dramatised talk-show therapy - and to be fair, it's honest about its intentions. But as cinema, it's just really bad, strident pulp.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This deceptively slim film might not be Kiarostami at his most heavyweight, but it's a rewarding and mischievous slice of cerebral entertainment.
Revealing, moving and entirely individual.
As close as cinema comes to modern British Chekhov.
This hugely entertaining cross-genre tale of a rural manhunt contrives to meld cop and cowboy elements into a rattling nail-biter.
Thirty years after AIDS first made its horrific impact, documentarist David Weissman has made a powerful and intimate testament to the epidemic's effect on San Francisco's gay community.
Other than a few droll period references and a handsomely evoked, quaintly drab early 1960s Paris, there's little else to distinguish this heavy-handed romantic comedy.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a shame to think of this heroically uncompromising director shutting up shop, but if he does, The Turin Horse is a magnificent farewell.
A classy, witty portrait of French president Nicolas Sarkozy -- and a very rare example of a political biopic made while the subject is still in power.
Using both longueurs and repetitions, Dumont has a way of holding our attention by refusing us the expected answers.
The ensemble acting is pitch perfect, and no-frills photography makes Seoul's streets a functional but characterful stage for this subtlest of farces.
An oddball, pithy political romcom, The Names of Love has vigour, intelligence to spare, and a winning -- if unlikely -- romantic duo at its lead.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Tree Of Life pushes American cinema into regions uncharted since Stanley Kubrick's heyday.
A Frankensteinian recombination of elements from earlier Almodóvar films - among them, Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down! and Law Of Desire.
An enigmatic but utterly distinctive and troubling film.
Bonnie is a touching tribute to the unbridled childhood imagination -- quite clearly, the kind of child who grows up to be a Pixar animator.
His films can be uncomfortably navel-gazing, and that's the case in this somewhat maudlin contemplation of the woes of film-making and the life artistic.
Lively and literate, Inglourious Basterds feels fresher than any Tarantino film in a while. Even so, smart as his writing is, it wouldn't kill him to see a blue pencil now and again.

Some von Trier fans will welcome his return to the elaborate visual invention he abandoned with the founding of Dogme. But in the wider world, Antichrist will prove too loopy and coarse for art-house audiences.
The Goob is less about linear narrative than presenting a fragmentary drift of events and a spirit of place that's deeply claustrophobic.
An incredibly rich and entertaining (not to say, laudably malevolent) film that far transcends its already way-out title premise.

This film is so different from The Apple and so striking that it can only encourage us to see Samira Makhmalbaf as a very distinctive sensibility, working to develop her own film language with conspicuous success.
Perfect Blue is a delirious, culturally astute invention.
A desperately hit-and-miss affair.
Tarr's true achievement is to attain the condition of silence, and of bottomless, awesomely inscrutable nightmare.
Wooden horse, wooden acting, wouldn't bother if I were you.

Orson Welles said a film studio was the best train-set a boy could have, but The Life Aquatic is something else: Anderson uses the sound stages of Cinecittá like a kid playing with toy boats in the bath. He makes one hell of a splash.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Nashville effectively founded the school of American improv-ensemble cinema.
For all the larking and swiving and the odd orgiastic tableau, The Libertine is an extremely sombre, thoughtful work.
A passionate, historically important film.
Sunshine is dazzling, but not quite a blinder - your eyeballs may be singed, but don't expect any long-lasting effects on your cosmic consciousness.
Good-natured but somewhat half-baked.
A flawlessly observed piece of street realism, and an unforgiving parable of American economic reality.

The Man From London bears all the trademarks of Tarr's recent films: dense chiaroscuro, sparely deployed dialogue, a vividly evoked locale, and fluidly wandering camera movements drawn out over hypnotically extended takes.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: One of European cinema's most distinctive stylists, and darkest humourists, returns with another tragi-comic panorama of the human condition.
Breillat here shakes historical drama out of its petticoats, with a torrid but rigorously executed tale of bohemian amour fou.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Synecdoche, New York finally feels bitter, hollow and adolescent: like a gargantuan music video conceived for an emo band with a penchant for Pirandello.
Don't Look Back, an initially intriguing, ultimately incoherent mind-bender.
movie_title: Ne Te Retourne Pas (Don't Look Back) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A Prophet works both as hard-edged, painstaking detailed social realism and as a compelling genre entertainment.

Soderbergh deserves all credit for attempting a very un-Hollywood project, an objective, forensic war film in the lineage of Pontecorvo's The Battle of Algiers, and as Benicio del Toro is convincing as the warrior in decline.
A rock-doc that celebrates the instrument without overly fretting (as it were) about the hardware.

Fincher treats Roth's script with a visual bravura and narrative gusto far beyond the usual capacities of the Hollywood mainstream. Benjamin Button is a poetic, virtuoso feat, as eloquent and rapturous as CGI-era cinema gets.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Kaurismäki works with a superb Franco-Finnish cast to bring us a typically modest but shining French-language gem that sees him magnificently back on form after the slight dip of 2006's Lights In The Dusk.
A lighter register than most Leigh films, but the content is as psychologically and dramatically rich as ever.
It's best described as introspective melodrama, yet both visually and tonally, it's still quintessential Ceylan.
A top-of-the-range family melodrama sparingly told and austerely framed, Claudel's tale of guilt, grief and redemption will have viewers thinking deep and weeping long.
It's cynical business as usual for Claude Chabrol, who offers plentiful style and psychological finesse, if few surprises, in his latest jaundiced and sophisticated entertainment.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While Filth And Wisdom may not quite inhabit the same Hall of Shame as Shanghai Surprise, Body of Evidence and (God save us) Swept Away, it's likely to be forgotten as quickly as most of them.
An entertaining, often very funny, but ultimately revealing and unsettling film about a US Army camp in the Mojave Desert where Iraq War conditions are simulated for training purposes.
As well as being an elegant, if studiedly small-scale landscape film, the film is also texturally rich.

Vigorously edited and energetically shot, Mermin's film gradually runs out of steam, with too much repetitive on-set footage simply reiterating the message that film-making is a crazy business, in Mumbai or elsewhere.
Rithy Panh's cinema is an exemplary case of the imperative to bear witness.
Swinton is as mesmerising as ever, although the show is stolen by the two Kevins - teenager Ezra Miller and youngster Jasper Newell.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This is a solid, sometimes provocative piece, although substantially more old school than the knowingly hip revisionism of Sofia Coppola's Marie Antoinette.
[W]e're carried along not just by the momentum of events, but by the precision with which they're depicted.
[A] bracing and unexpected offering from a director we thought we knew.
Rush is pure 'print the myth' stuff -- but since both its heroes really are myths, it gets away with it, with more grace and vigor than you might expect.
Prisoners -- sometimes awkwardly, for the most part persuasively -- does a delicate balancing act between outright nightmare and naturalism.
[A] deeply alluring contemplation of Macao as reality and myth; an investigation of the locale's past, present, and future; and a fascinating experiment in form ...
movie_title: A Última Vez Que Vi Macau (The Last Time I Saw Macao) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Allen seems uninterested in pushing his material beyond impersonally generic, or even in thinking things through.

As opposed to the bleak view of sexual subjugation in Kadosh, Amos Gitai's 1999 film about Hasidic marriage, Fill the Void sees Burshtein fortrightly and wittily asserting that this is how her community lives.

Sniping at what's already been celebrated as a major national triumph always looks not-quite-cricket, but Madden's film is transparently one of those things that the British Do So Well, and the Americans fund so handsomely.
Life of Riley isn't for everyone, and I have to admit that it wasn't entirely for me... Resnais is doing something simpler, lighter, and in many ways, more academic and safe.
Child's Pose treads a delicate line between social horror and comedy-so much so that, as with Lazarescu, it's not always immediately apparent that the comedy is present.
In warming quite a lot to Jimmy P, it's possible that I've gravitated to what Desplechin's long-term admirers might regard as the wrong film.
Stalingrad is certainly watchable in its overwrought bombast, but it's less a film than a $30m ideological monument.
However you read it, the film is compelling and audaciously candid in its erotic charge, while an ending that literally leaves us in the dark is one of the most haunting sign-offs in recent cinema.
Findlay narrates in huge chunks of religiose voice-over. "Nothing has been without purpose - nothing," she concludes. Well, perhaps not nothing.
This fascinating film really belongs to those people whose names never made the history books, barely even their local newspaper headlines.
Along with its anger, Fleifel's revealing film contrives, against the odds, to derive everyday humour from the refugee experience.

This is a story about people floating through space, and Alfonso Cuarón's feature brilliantly contrives to make the viewer feel similarly untethered, to often thrilling effect. This is surely the closest cinema comes to three-dimensional virtual abseiling.
Wisconsin Death Trip is always lyrical, sometimes blackly farcical, and sometimes terrifying, as it reveals the romanticised American frontier's true desperation.

With Anderson's images, seductive as they are, we can ultimately only guess -- what Margot's plays are about, or who Etheline's suitors are... And that makes Anderson's film an exhilarating experience, a real jungle gym for the imagination.
The Big Sleep is as fresh and perverse as ever, and remains one of Hollywood's most entrancingly strange bedtime stories.

Despite its faintly mechanical construction, Blast From The Past is very classy, and the improbable comic duo of Spacek and Walken provide the manic edge. Silverstone is good, engagingly grouchy but Fraser is indeed a blast.
Svengali ought to be sharper, but this good-natured, clunky labour of love feels about as fresh as a 2002 copy of the NME.
The initial Hitchcockian tension soon slackens into slop, with a dash of lukewarm eroticism.
It's all hard to dislike, but you're more likely to find mordant gallows humour in The Lego Movie.

Former dancer Caity Lotz is good at lethal kicks and twitchy cyborg movements, but her ingenue manner and baby-doll voice don't make her any more convincing as a cybernetics genius than as a robo-femme super-soldier.
Built around Rumsfeld's obsessive habit of pumping out memos, the film yields little insight into the deep agenda of America's war in Iraq, nor does it crack its subject's polished, affable veneer.
France has every reason to be smug about its cultural heritage, but the nation has developed a terribly pious way of commemorating its great and good in biopics.
Exquisitely crafted if somewhat academic - an "ambient thriller", if there's such a thing.

Is Fritz Lang's 1927 epic Metropolis the most influential film ever? It certainly spawned the cinema of futurism, and watching it today. it's uncanny to see how many shadows of cinema yet to come it already contains.
What's finally impressive about Noah, even to those of us who are hardly unconditional Aronofskians, is the degree of unbending faith on which this massively ambitious venture is built.
You thought there was nothing new to add to the vampire genre? So, apparently, did Jarmusch, which is why Only Lovers Left Alive luxuriates in a curious end-of-an-era melancholy ...
Camille Claudel 1915 is a film of stark, sober rewards, and possibly Dumont's finest.
But even if it is merely a sketch or fragment, an elegant offhand gesture, this film is pure Denis and richly unsettling.
Le Week-End's melancholy and sometimes downright bitter disillusionment are plain to see behind the ooh-la-la veneer.
You don't see many films that so overtly address the Human Condition -- with capital letters -- as intense, contemplative Alpine drama The Wall.
Hanekes absolute control makes the film intensely involving and quietly moving, rather than harrowing.
At times, the film achieves a hypnotic intensity. But for much of the time, Carax too visibly strains at poetic resonance
A film of bristling intelligence that will delight lovers of cerebral upmarket cinema.
There is a vision here, certainly, but the film feels genuinely, bracingly experimental in that it seems to be searching for its own meaning and form, rather than asserting them ready-made.
Possibly the slowest and most contemplative war film ever made, In the Fog is a delicately complex work of shifting perspectives.
Colossal Youth demands to be seen more than once.
Saraband is a commandingly restrained final composition and -- as the theme of classical musicianship suggests -- very much an affair of close attention to the nuances of performance.
Cosmopolis may, like Packer's limo, be an elaborately conceived but essentially vacant vehicle -- yet it has a master at the wheel.
For those who like this sort of hyper-controlled, hugely intelligent work, Barbara will be a must.
The pleasure in The Cabin in the Woods comes from its audacious tuggings-away of the dramatic rug under your feet.
Playful and wildly imaginative to the last, this film shows Ruiz going out dreaming, and laughing.
Hugely entertaining.
Back on track after the misfiring über-cool of The Limits Of Control, Jarmusch delivers a passionate and consummately chic essay on science, music, time and above all love.
The bedroom scenes are to be taken in the context of an emotionally and psychologically rich drama that touches more nerves, more satisfyingly, than most realist narrative manages.
Even when he's talking technical, as he mostly does, Stewart's engaging, no-nonsense good humour shines through.
Likeably modest, White Reindeer is no-frills sitcom stuff, but its tartness can make you squirm deliciously.
[A]rguably delves into country matters more deeply than any precursor in cinema.
I can't remember when a film last gave me such a surge of pure pleasure -- no, outright euphoria -- as The Great Beauty.
[A]n odyssey into the past, into missed opportunities, and into the complexities of an everyday family of malcontents.
[I]t's about a series of seemingly disconnected topics linked by an abstract idea, and by a certain exploratory spirit.
Saving Mr. Banks depicts cinema as a perverse nexus of capitalism and psychoanalysis.
[A] tender, wry, deceptively modest package -- and the closer you look, the more it reveals itself to be the proverbial Movie For Our Times.
Davies vividly catches the mood of Rattigan's tattered post-war England, of painfully observed proprieties on one hand, untameable desire on the other.
What prevails throughout Beyond Outrage is a rigorous, downbeat classicism.
Writer-director Sebastián Lelio, whose fourth feature this is, has a confident way of parceling out exuberance and melancholy in a setting of mundane everyday realism.
Lanzmann is a sort of counter-exorcist: instead of dispelling ghosts of the past, he makes sure that haunted sites stay haunted ...

Boyle set out to make this particular film rather than a gritty social panorama along the lines of Brazilian favela drama City of God. But keeping us cheerful takes the edge off the tougher insights into India.
In Bloom so triumphantly, albeit modestly, transcends its category that it's really quite special.

If you're open to films that fearlessly twist the conventions, and that mine the language of sound and image for their own strange potential, you'll get a kick from this rivetingly inventive, abrasively un-British piece of nightmare cinema.
Conner Chapman and Shaun Thomas are terrific fresh finds for Barnard, and the film is a triumph in the direction of young untried actors.
It's easy to categorize Murdoch's film as a vanity project, but if it is, it's a very honest one.
It's all a bit joyless and over-decorated, and the terrific Céline Sallette, from TV's The Returned, has little to do but fret on the sidelines.
As much as a downbeat comedy of bourgeois mores, Archipelago is a sort of claustrophobic horror story, set in a place of no easy escape.
A smug, manic London comedy that feels as if it's come several years too late to the Richard Curtis party.
In this hyper-intricate construction of false leads and surprise reversals, the ultimate dupe - and a very willing one - is the viewer.
Malek's befuddled ingénue, with his weary frog-baby eyes and that incongruously jutting puppet-ish jaw, ensure a human immediacy that the film's formal elaboration sometimes militates against.
The film's textures and syntax are so strange and alluring that Suwichakornpong's film becomes far more than the sum of its disparate parts.
movie_title: By the Time It Gets Dark (Dao khanong) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The solace that we can all take from Suntan, however, is that this is an extraordinary, exuberant, and inventive piece of cinema, and a finely crafted character sketch and essay in dark moral comedy.

Here's a rare period drama that contrives to minimize the gap between its events and our experience of watching them. Notwithstanding its frocks and bonnets, it feels as much a present-tense story as any film set in our own time.
An acutely intelligent, finely acted and - despite its cerebral edge - emotionally rich piece.
movie_title: Let the Sunshine In (Un beau soleil intérieur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film's visual execution and spare narrative style give it a timeless dimension that will lend some modestly exportable clout to an approachable and appealingly laconic drama.
Okja is a classic case of a film that you emerge from not knowing quite who it's intended for.
This is a ruthlessly controlled drama that achieves its powerful effect by holding back when its dramatic content is most intense.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a dazzlingly executed, hugely enjoyable act of stylistic homage, but also the poignant story of a dysfunctional marriage and an insightful recreation of a critical and contradiction-ridden period of modern French history.

Napalm feels like a missed opportunity to get much deeper under the skin of a nation that Lanzmann clearly knows better than most observers, and for whose citizens he feels more compassion and understanding than they are often granted.
Uneven dramatic treatment makes for a less than entirely cogent modern tragedy.

An inert lead performance from Mantas Janciauskas gives the impression not of a man plunging into the very heart of darkness, but of a student who's made a very bad decision about how to spend his gap year.
As ever, Gatlif can't be faulted on energy, and world music lovers will relish the fairly diverse examples of a specific music genre.
Adventurous viewers are invited to take the road less travelled, and then some, in Mimosas, an enigmatic mountain odyssey by Morocco-based Spanish director Oliver Laxe.
A teasing, tricksy, hugely entertaining, in some ways old-fashioned divertissement - although for 'old-fashioned', you could say classic, with a post-modern twist.
movie_title: Based on a True Story (D'après une histoire vraie) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Never outright iconoclastic, still less hostile, Redoubtable simply places the odd banana skin under the great ean-Luc Godard's feet, with irreverent fondness.

The diffuse nature of the narrative, the way in which the film sometimes seems reluctant to focus, makes it something other than the simpler, more direct, more obvious movie that it might have been-a spectacle of the pedagogic urge to destroy.

More than any of Morris's films, The B-Side is directly about the mystery of capturing a person's identity on film...This likeable close-up portrait may not be one of his most substantial films, but it's his most likeable and most casual.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It perhaps emerges that, the more interested an artist is in a whole variety of different things, the less they may need to impose a single stamp on every work they create in response.
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage À Travers Le Cinéma Français) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It imparts the thrill of witnessing the hedonism and lawlessness-both sexual and artistic-of a bygone culture. You also feel an almost tragic surge of melancholia watching it: where and when, you wonder, will cinema ever get quite this wild again?

There's more of an architecture inherent to the film than if it were simply a succession of staged readings by Blanchett-but those readings, and her transformations, are mesmerizing, and often very funny.
The way The Untamed similarly creeps in oblique moves towards its revelation is equally unnerving. But it has something else that also unnerves and fascinates -- the face of Simone Bucio.
Even so, Columbus is intensely moving-only you have to be prepared to slip between the lines of its perfectly formed geometry to find the sources of its emotion.
It's not always easy to know what's going on in Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk-which makes the film seem all the more convincing as an evocation of war.
When digital cinema captures texture as sensuously and as precisely as this, a film can be a treat not just for blockbuster adepts but for the most rarefied aesthetes too.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At moments in Jesús... you're close to thinking you've seen it all before, but a delve into the vacant world of a teenage boy and his pals later takes a turn towards something different.
Useful as a teaching tool, strictly functional as cinema.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Everything, Everything isn't without intelligence or charm, but just because a film is set in a sanitised environment doesn't mean that it should look or feel as antiseptically, oppressively pastel as this.

In its thoughtful, pragmatic way, La Soledad is an inventive and insightful exercise in exploring a real location down to the last cobwebbed corner. And politically, it depicts a desperate state of affairs, but with hope and quiet energy.
You Were Never Really Here is a bold piece of storytelling, with a dream-like feel that evokes its hellish, predominantly nocturnal world very compellingly.
Without over-explaining, the film suggests that beneath the elegance of Boa Viagem and, by implication, respectable Brazilian society, there runs an undertow of filth.

The film shifts so continually and so unpredictably between bleakness and whimsy, between the sugared and the sordid, that it's very hard for viewers to stay invested in the fiction, still less in the characters.
The most enjoyable film yet from a director whose conceptual seriousness has often seemed daunting.
The Woman Who Left may not represent Diaz at his absolute peak, but it's a powerful, thoughtful melodrama that pulls you into its world and delivers a number of irresistible emotional coups.
movie_title: The Woman Who Left (Ang babaeng humayo) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A powerfully austere nineteenth-century drama, and an uncompromising attempt to make that rare thing, a genuine British art film.
Roy's sometimes ethereal presence strikes a forceful but delicate note as a woman who is at once facing a mystery and who is at the same time a mystery herself.
Wang makes Chan Is Missing to a similar recipe-the film is imbued with, and is entirely about, Chinese-ness, but adopts a quintessentially American form, the film noir mystery.

A laid-back feminist fable about a young woman pulling her life together over a complicated summer, Franco-Belgian drama Baden Baden is a confident, witty debut for French writer-director Rachel Lang.
Certain Women, despite giving each of its stories a brief encapsulating coda, isn't merely open-ended-it seems to deny the very idea of narrative closure.
It made me chuckle, made me wince a little-and it made me enjoy telling people about it and watching them squint dubiously at me as if they suspected me of making it all up.
For all its seriousness and its occasional glimpses of despair and spiritual darkness, Son of Joseph exudes and inspires joy.
movie_title: The Son of Joseph (Le fils de Joseph) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An ambitious hybrid narrative from director Izu Ojukwu.
A film that not only amply merits its name, but would make Norman Bates scratch his head at the sheer weirdness of what goes on here behind closed doors.
The treatment for this action spoof could have been written on the back of a matchbox - of a single match, even.
The first hour keeps the suspense admirably taut, the 1967 period setting and sense of domestic claustrophobia bringing a twist of style that puts this way ahead of the first ho-hum chapter.
If you like kids' movies served with a side of po-mo knowingness, as in The Lego Movie and the Jason Segel/Amy Adams Muppets film, you'll have a great time.

As feelgood stories of empowerment go, this has a ring of authenticity and mixes intelligence with irreducible emotional immediacy.

This subtle but passionate essay on teenage identity and desire not only honours the Kurt Cobain school of teen spirit but brings something fresh and richly intelligent to the field of US independent cinema.
This tautly-constructed, intensely claustrophobic drama offers a sometimes nerve-shredding depiction of what happens when conflict impinges on domestic space.
Chavela is a vivid portrayal of an artistic, social and sexual rebel whose difficult but finally triumphant life finally proved that there sometimes really are second acts in showbiz lives.
A striking feature debut for director Rafael Kapelinski ...
This relatively concise passion project won't, in the end, stop viewers getting the cramps that come with much longer sittings.

Delicate psychological insight, a strong aesthetic signature and two affecting, restrained performances by Alexandra Borbély and Géza Morcsányi overcome any familiarity, as well as occasional hints of preciousness.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: There's the stuff of a terrific chamber piece here, but it's drastically unbalanced by Geoffrey Rush's showy whimsicality as the mercurial maestro.
kogonada ... brings a deeply idiosyncratic stylistic and dramatic sensibility to a story that's not just a character piece, but also a finely nuanced study of people, space and consciousness.

130-plus minutes is a long time to wait for a glimpse of what someone is, rather than what she's not.
Austere and melancholic, but also marked by dry minimalist humour.
movie_title: United States of Love (Estados Unidos de Amor) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Doctor Strange seems to represent the point at which the art of CGI and the discipline of imagining visual images spatially seems to have reached a sublime degree of 3D complexity.
An elegant piece that will give you plenty to think about, if you ever get a quiet moment.

If there's anything worse than a film with no point, it's one that's all point and nothing but.
Ultimately the message is banal and rather repellent: brainwork wrecks your health.

This atavistic Christians-vs-Moors narrative doesn't belong in the present day, and that's no doubt why so many people are addicted to it: it's so ideologically overstated that it can easily be brushed off as harmlessly quaint escapism.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A reminder that politicians' maintenance of their image is an intricate and slippery dance, with the public not always allowed to know all the steps.
Ruiz wonderfully pastiches the stiffness, the talky longueurs, the abrupt discontinuity of the telenovela style...
movie_title: The Wandering Soap Opera (La Telenovela Errante) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Based on a play by Tomohiro Maekawa, Before We Vanish-its Japanese title means "Strolling Invaders"-may not be prime Kurosawa, and it's oddly uneven in tone, but it has an ease about it that's intensely engaging.

... it's engaging and distinctive, although it may fade from your mind like a lurid dream the moment it's over. [Full review in Spanish]

This intelligent, economical study carries its literary and philosophical influences with grace, and achieves a provocative thrust and an emotional power all the more effective for its tone of detachment.
movie_title: Shock Waves - Diary of My Mind (Journal de ma tête) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Rey is a bold, freakish marvel, a bottle in the ocean of cinema, but worth cracking open-it contains not one message but a whole mass of them, scrawled in many different scripts and colors with artisanal passion and (sometimes) genuine inspiration.

movie_title: Tony Conrad: Completely in the Present (2016)

movie_title: The Lion Sleeps Tonight (Le lion est mort ce soir) (2017)

movie_title: The House by the Sea (La villa) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This won't raise Toback's ever-wavering profile, but at least it proves him game for a challenge and unashamed to look, let's say, studenty in his earnestness - which feels somehow commendable for a director of his vintage.
movie_title: The Private Life of a Modern Woman (2017)

Disappointing in its simplification of the 60s as merely a burst of dizzy spectacle.

movie_review_blurb: Despite its bleak theme, the film brims with anarchic life.

movie_title: Wet Woman in the Wind (Kaze ni nureta onna) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the emotional depth that Kim brings to her depiction of Younghee, one of this year's most fully rounded pictures of a complex female personality, sexually and emotionally aware of who she is, and seeing her struggles through for better or worse.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a stunning, provocative work that will get animation buffs buzzing.
movie_title: Have a Nice Day (Hao Ji Le) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: An elegant, highly intelligent attempt to humanise a legend - while showing its subject's acute awareness of what it means to become a legend.

Watch absolutely anything else.

movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Slow West is a clipped, super-economical neo-Western-or rather a meta-Western musing on certain conventions of the genre that refuses to die but continues to mutate, these days usually into more or less ironic forms.
