An emotionally observant character study.
An explosive family drama whose intense performances can't always compensate for such a heavy-handed scenario, Bad Hurt nonetheless marks a promising directorial debut from playwright Mark Kemble.
It's a surprising and often thought-provoking effort from a filmmaker who has never chosen to take the simple path, confirming Larrain as one of the more genuine talents working in cinema today.
It's hard not to watch the somber Jane without thinking that this is one of those cases where the making-of could be better - and definitely more fun - than the final product.
Both a powerful allegory for post-war regeneration and a rich Hitchcockian tale of mistaken identity.
Treasure still confirms Porumboiu's status as one of the more fascinating minds working in cinema today.
600 Miles doesn't generate the level of nail-biting suspense one expects here, languishing in lengthy driving scenes and other bits of mundane storytelling.

The horrors of the battlefield come home to roost in ways that are both riveting and deeply disturbing in Of Men and War, a remarkable chronicle of Iraq War veterans suffering from the devastating effects of PTSD.
A visually mesmerizing exploration of man, nature and the destructive powers of colonialism.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: We Did It on a Song deserves extra credit for trying to pull off something new.
movie_title: We Did It on a Song (Chante ton bac d'abord) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A sprawling, emotionally absorbing tale of young love from Franco-Tunisian auteur Abdellatif Kechiche.
A surreal sci-fi period piece that reimagines mid-20th century Paris as a smog-filled, steam-powered Napoleonic empire whose future lies in the hands of an orphaned young woman.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An impressively made if highly juvenile version of a literary classic.
A gritty and compassionate look at an adolescence riddled by violence, punishment and the idea that rehabilitation is a long way off, but not entirely out of the question.
Gripping if not altogether satisfying.
movie_title: Next Time I'll Aim for the Heart (La prochaine fois je viserai le coeur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Nadav Lapid not only makes this rich and rather strange tale convincing on screen, but he does so with the aesthetic prowess of a first-class auteur.
Public and private lives clash together and create a decent amount of laughs, in the shot-on-the-fly French indie dramedy Age of Panic.
movie_title: Age of Panic (La Bataille de Solférino) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's a familiar story that's handled with delicacy in places, yet lacks some much-needed intensity.
Quebecois auteur Denys Arcand shows that he still has An Eye for Beauty in his latest dramatic feature, but he doesn't have much of a knack for storytelling in this extremely benign tale.
movie_title: An Eye for Beauty (Le règne de la beauté) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The price of fame and the cost of fandom come crashing together in some amusingly suspenseful ways in Elle l'adore, the debut feature from French actress-turned-director Jeanne Herry.
Offbeat, exuberant and occasionally quite hilarious.
What makes the movie work are the lively performances, both from the supporting cast and from Cranston ...
This questionable historical thriller is a dictatorship of poor filmmaking.
The Girl in the Photographs marks an amusingly gory sophomore effort from writer-director Nick Simon.
A film that's a pleasure to watch but not always one to follow.
movie_title: Land And Shade (La Tierra Y La Sombra) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Regis Roinsard's impressive debut is a love letter to 50s filmmaking, but one that lacks a real heart.
Only ardent followers will gravitate to this enigmatic work.
Almodovar's campy in-flight comedy takes off and certainly gets off, but is otherwise a rocky ride.
Less a succinct narrative than a meandering portrait of several ultra-rich, ultra-empty thirtysomethings who waste away their days with sex, drugs and ennui.
A heaping pile of cliches doesn't prevent this touchingly simplistic tale from exuding a strong and universal emotional appeal.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the overstuffed storytelling, Sfar and co-director Antoine Delesvaux provide an incredible palette of visuals culled from the style Sfar originally created on paper.
Daniel Auteuil offers a crowd-pleasing remake of a Marcel Pagnol classic.
A transfixing meditation on religious conviction, post-colonial strife and the force of actors who elevate every gesture to a loftier domain.
Liam Neeson stars in a paranoid caper showcasing the city of Berlin.
Pic speeds by in 80 minutes (sans end credits) of nonstop gunplay, pileups (of people, not cars) and occasionally exhilarating location work throughout Paris' streets and subways.
A Cat in Paris is easy enough on the eyes yet never quite justifies feature-length status.
This ludicrous outing from helmer Christian Alvart and scribe Ray Wright takes its psycho-satanic babble much too seriously, and should elicit more laughs than frights.
With a meandering 2 1/2-hour edit that could easily lose a reel or two, the fun gives way to several longueurs midway through.

The remake ups the adrenaline factor, and features strong perfs across the board, yet feels bogged down by a weighty love triangle and a subject that merits more than the old-school good vs. evil approach.

Euro-financed production throws large chunks of change at a corporate espionage saga spanning several continents, yet most of the money seems to have landed in locations, with too little allocated to the script and stunt departments.
Thoughtful and endearing.
Tightly wound and crafted, with robust performances by Kristin Scott Thomas and recurrent Spanish Don Juan Sergi Lopez, the pic offers a rough, no-frills take on a story as old as France itself.
A technically polished thriller marred by textbook filmmaking that grows increasingly dull as the plot wears on.

Both evocative and faithful in its depiction of the famed French singer's lascivious life, Gainsbourg (vie heroique) offers up a feast of memorable chansons and an almost endless parade of drop-dead-gorgeous muses.
A zits-and-all portrait of the weird, wild and incredibly awkward time of adolescence, Gallic laffer "The French Kissers" plants plenty of heart-wrenching gags right in the smacker.
A lively and often rather funny affair, dishing out oodles of sex, drugs and hip-hop, with plenty of below-the-belt humor a l'americaine.
The singing-and-dancing work for the basic excitement and energy of a live performance, but an additional boost of cinematic prowess is needed to sustain a similar rhythm on film.
A noisier, costlier version of Children of Men, yet lacking that film's social-political significance and jaw-dropping direction.
Heavy on the spice and cheap on the meat, Bangkok Dangerous adds plenty of Thai seasoning to the Hollywood lone-assassin recipe, but the result is only mildly pungent.
Film should score OK with hardcore gore fans, but others will expect martyrdom for sticking it out until the end.
Packed with plenty of drama, laughs and sentimental charm.
Paula van der Oest's biopic of South African poet Ingrid Jonker is conventional yet captivating thanks in large part to a terrific lead performance from Carice van Houten.

Riding in on the four ponies currently plaguing the Hollywood horror-thriller -- overstylized torture, whiplash editing, compulsive script reversals and crude neon lighting -- Horsemen brings its herd home to pasture in strictly predictable fashion.
Alain Resnais continues his career-long experiment in filmmaking with the playfully flamboyant melodrama Wild Grass.

With machines that are impressively more lifelike, and characters that are more and more like machines, Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen takes the franchise to a vastly superior level of artificial intelligence.
Whatever hints of originality lay in the series' previous editions have been all but sucked out of this one.
The pic reveals the hazards of taking Twilight Zone material too far and too seriously.
This second screen installment of Stephenie Meyer's bestselling series focuses, somewhat convincingly, on the emotions of an 18-year-old coping with her undying love of the undead.
While a colossal local release should yield Gallic gold, the pic looks to flounder in Anglo territories.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles 2: Arthur and the Revenge of Maltazard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Tautou's perf is one of her finest to date, revealing her character's headstrong personality through smart delivery and a permanent but attractive pout.
At once a Big Chill-style old-pal reunion story and an Invasion of the Body Snatchers homage doused in beer and bad-boy humor ...
Too giddy about its own nonconformism to keep the laughs going from start to finish.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Arthouse audiences could drink this down like a glass of Chardonnay.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: James Toback explores the realities behind the red carpet in this sharp and entertaining documentary.
Michel Gondry's surreal Gallic dramedy is less a visual feast than an all-you-can-eat buffet, and one that's rather hard to consume.

Left unfinished when River Phoenix died of drug-related causes in the middle of shooting, this terrifically played and superbly photographed three-hander reveals to what extent the 23-year-old star was an intense and unpredictable talent.
[An] uneven family dramedy.
Tightly crafted East German drama delivers strong performances and late rewards.
A hard-hitting exercise in beefy, brainless fun...
Uneven follow-up to Heartbreaker offers a similar pitch but significantly less laughs.
Adamson mixes magical realism with hard-hitting historical drama in a way that feels both contrived and questionable, even if the filmmakers clearly have their hearts in the right place.
Strong performances mark a mildly involving tale of four classical musicians hoping to make it to the next season.
Everything gets homogenized into a blandish whole, the impact of each story softened by the constant need to connect the dots.
Heartfelt but rather generic.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An engrossing and detailed crash course on the digital revolution.
Leaping back onto the screen with a new cast, crew, costume and a whole new array of daddy issues, The Amazing Spider-Man reboots the top grossing Marvel franchise to altogether satisfying results.
Although ambitions wind up preventing the film from delivering the kind of dramatic knock-out blow of A Separation, there's a similar underlying feeling of hopelessness.
This gloomy and penetrating psychological drama should receive steady art house play.
A bear and a mouse cause a major ruckus in this charming Franco-Belgian animated film.

A bizarre and baroque meditation on death, memory and the passage of time that ranks among the director's more cryptic works (of which there are several in his whopping 100+ feature filmography), though it does offer up a few pleasurable moments.
There are guilty pleasures to be had in this frenzied B starring Zoe Saldana, who gives an acrobatic performance that makes the overcooked material watchable.

Serving up a good ol' fashioned adventure flick that harkens back to the filmmaker's action-packed, tongue-in-cheek swashbucklers of the 1980s, Steven Spielberg's The Adventures of Tintin: The Secret of the Unicorn is a visually dazzling adaptation.
Never develops into an engaging portrait of love and loss among a trio of thirty-something Frenchies.
Coming-of-age tale tackles gender confusion with humor and heart.
This all-too timid affair features decent turns from stars Audrey Tautou and Francois Damiens, who do what they can with a threadbare plot and by-the-book direction.
A colorfully compelling kids flick with darker historical undertones, Zarafa reps a smart and successful freshman animation effort from writer-director Remi Bezancon.
This cleverly conceived, behind-the-scenes tale features fine lead performances and enough nods to the epic group's early days to interest fans outside the U.K.

Though Lights Out initially aims at something vaguely disturbing, its rather lightweight resolution all too neatly ties up the trajectories of characters who remained compelling as long as their lives seemed messy and real.
Never much more than an extended sketch comedy whose longer segments tend to wear out their welcome.
Moving French drama tackles the Israeli-Palestinian conflict via a pair of prodigal sons accidentally switched at birth.
A quirky murder mystery where the world's most famous blond gets resurrected in rural France.
The film constantly toys with the expectations of both its characters and the audience, transforming a classic three-way tale of mistaken identities into something much more mysterious and troubling.
[Offers] up an enticing amuse-bouche to an artist whose body of work has become essential viewing.
The revolution is rather clumsily televised in Operation Libertad, an unconvincing mash-up of found footage filmmaking and 70s leftist nostalgia from Swiss documentarian Nicolas Wadimoff.

Turning one of the darkest moments in modern French history into syrupy historical drama, writer-director Rose Bosch's The Round Up is a polished, pathos-driven re-creation of the Vichy regime's mass imprisonment and disposal of 13,000 Parisian Jews.
A movie that can feel both original and somewhat conventional - a classic working girl rom-com with just enough kookiness to set itself apart from the pack.

As a work entirely dedicated to revealing the artistry of its lead performer, Gallienne's sophomore effort ultimately does the trick, and by the time the curtain falls one longs to see what d'Hermy will do next.

It's like Ingmar Bergman's Scenes from a Marriage condensed into a shorter timeframe and only a handful of rooms, although its depiction of a crumbling relationship can be just as complex, if not quite as emotionally resonant during its final stages.

Renner and Imbert spend more time dishing out jokes than they do weaving the kind of meaningful narrative that made Ernest & Celestine so special, yet while Fox is more of a slaphappy romp than a morality play, there's still a method to the madness.
movie_title: The Big Bad Fox and Other Tales (Le grand méchant renard et autres contes) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A tough and moving educational drama.
Once the plot kicks in after the first reel, things head pretty much where you'd expect and all the sisterly bouts of love, hate and lamentation can grow rather tedious ...

Sure, his script is yet another tale of several strangers teaming up to fight the flesh-eaters, but the director favors a more eclectic approach that's equal parts George Romero, Robert Bresson and Monty Python.
There's not much to chew on beyond all the pretty pictures and the two attractive leads.
movie_title: If You Saw His Heart (Si tu voyais son coeur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a clever concept that's fairly well executed, if a tad contrived in spats, with tension that slowly boils to the surface as the zombies inevitably come back for a bite.
This moody, heavy-handed tale of mourning and loss never quite reaches its intended emotional catharsis, even if there's an impressive scope to what Laurent is trying to accomplish.
A sprawling cri de coeur set in the heart of modern-day Casablanca, Nabil Ayouch's Razzia is an intense network narrative that nearly collapses under the weight of its own ambitions.

If Number One doesn't always convince on a thematic or dramatic level, it's propped up by an excellent cast - beginning with Devos, who manages to appear both poised and completely flustered in the same shot ...
An easily digestible love story-cum-survival tale that tosses two excellent actors in the snow and lets them do their thing.
A tough and sentimental expat drama.
A sober, quietly affecting wartime drama.
There's something so disarming about Phillip and Dell's relationship that you're gradually sucked into it without asking too many questions.

If the movie runs long in places, the vibrant performances from Worthy and the rest of the cast help push things ahead, and there are enough dynamo battles from start to finish to keep hungry rap fans satisfied.
It's got a nervously eerie feel to it that's grounded in Canet's gripping turn as a daddy out to do good for his estranged family.
There's no real voice in the storytelling, nothing distinctive about the imagery, if it's not a doubling up on the violence and gore, and the result doesn't remotely resonate in the same way.
Haunting and perplexing.
It's all a bit overlong and over-the-top, although the lead turn from rising star Finnegan Oldfield (Nocturama) is almost enough to make it work.
Deneuve. Depardieu. A picturesque French village. What could possibly go wrong? How about almost everything?
This mildly entertaining and very family friendly outing will play best with tykes who aren't quite ready for the more sophisticated meta-fictions of Pixar or DreamWorks.
The pacing is fast enough to gloss over the movie's rather limited imagination. And although it's not exactly on par with the major studios, the animation work is nonetheless impressive ...
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A thoughtful, albeit predictable, look at transgender issues ...
An awful if affable mash-up of Dirty Grandpa and Meatballs that follows a bunch of senior citizens and their reluctant 20-something counselor over the course of one wet hot Gallic summer.

A Brothers Grimm tale is given a rather grim if beautifully rendered makeover in The Girl Without Hands (La Jeune fille sans mains), which marks the feature debut of French animation director Sebastien Laudenbach.
movie_title: The Girl Without Hands (La Jeune fille sans mains) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary-style feature that uses its unique setting to drive an otherwise minimalist coming-of-age story.
This one-trick pony gets in a few good gags during the opening reels before heading to the most predictable and clichéd places imaginable.
It's either a brilliant idea or a recipe for disaster, and in the hands of writer-director Sou Abadi, the film falls somewhere in between.
movie_title: Some Like It Veiled (Cherchez la femme) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Feels like an exercise in genre-bending for the pure sake of it.
Essential viewing for cinephiles and Francophiles alike.
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage À Travers Le Cinéma Français) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The circus theme already feels played out from the start, while the story heads in mostly predictable directions despite the limited pleasure of seeing those mighty morphin power crackers in action.
A compelling if somewhat cliched look at the downside of fame.
movie_title: The Price of Success (Le Prix du succès) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... an inventive if somewhat mawkish sci-fi melodrama in which a terminally ill hipster finds himself regenerated in the near-distant future, only to learn that he may have been better off dead.
Worthy intentions aren't enough to overcome a half-baked scenario and a bunch of jokes that never seem to have been developed beyond the nesting stage.
There's hardly anything that comes across as original in Conrad's story, although the nitty-gritty details on modeling offer up some peculiar examples of fashion's ugly underbelly.
A well-performed drama of mutual dependence.
movie_title: The Party's Over (La fête est finie) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Has some clever ideas and well-crafted moments, but in terms of horror fodder, it's so pared down you'll practically miss it if you blink.
movie_title: The Night Eats the World (La nuit a dévoré le monde) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing look at female desire in the Muslim world.
movie_title: Of Skin and Men (L'amour des hommes) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: What [Cohen] doesn't do very well is concoct a good story or create characters that resemble real people, which is why Heist can ... be a bit of a chore.

If Ducasse is somewhat renowned for the simplicity of his dishes, for the way he can blend a few homegrown ingredients to achieve the perfect amalgam, then de Maistre definitely lathers the man with too much sauce.
movie_title: The Quest of Alain Ducasse (La Quête d'Alain Ducasse) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Funny in spats but overextending the Ch'ti concept to an ad nauseam degree ...
A intriguing tale of forbidden first love.
A stark and unsettling account of army life.
Game Girls doesn't really go beyond its fly-on-the-wall approach to its heroines, offering us lots of intimacy but nothing that really sets its story within a greater social or political context.
Infused with plenty of documentary-like authenticity, especially in its portrayal of a group of young men trying to exorcise their demons.
Offers ample proof that mass corporate agriculture is the wrong way to go for this land or any land.
movie_title: A Journey to the Fumigated Towns (2018)

movie_review_blurb: [The] movie functions as a form of cinematic group therapy ... by the closing credits we can only hope that some of these kids have been put on the right track.
There's a conviction to the storytelling that can't be denied, and no matter what your tastes are it's hard not to be moved by Etienne's struggle to find his voice amid so much doubt and disillusion.
An enticing premise that fails to catch fire.
For a movie about such a grim subject matter, the result can be surprisingly pleasant and even uplifting.
A comedy that offers one or two good jokes amid lots of shouting matches and easy bouts of slapstick.
movie_title: Return of the Hero (Le Retour du Héros) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Overstays its welcome and fails to deliver in the final stretch.
Mixes high craft, surrealist humor and extremely dark themes - of trauma, death, corruption and manipulation - in ways that hold together rather well.
movie_title: See You Up There (Au revoir là-haut) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The problem is that the more Marchal embellishes things, the less credible his film ultimately becomes, and by the time Antoine's story comes full circle Carbon is mostly running on fumes.
All That Divides Us is like one of those cartoons of a caveman beating a woman with a club and then dragging her off by her long mane. There's practically nothing in this movie that rings true ...
movie_title: All That Divides Us (Tout nous sépare) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The directors get much mileage out of Nathalie's toxic behavior, with Viard drawing laughs from what's actually an extremely sad, borderline disturbing tale of one fiftysomething woman's downward spiral into alcoholism, resentment and general misery.
A trippy visual feast that satisfies on an aesthetic level, if not always on a narrative one.
A well-observed portrait of a woman embarking on a new romance while also having a baby - though one that isn't hers to keep.
movie_title: Diane Has the Right Shape (Diane a les épaules) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are enough traces of the artist himself in the movie, from his many paintings to the famous letters he wrote to his brother and benefactor Theo, to please both experts and newbies, who should enjoy watching his work come to life on screen.
An intimately haunting mix of the personal and the historical.
A haunting portrait of Algerians coping with the aftereffects of war.
The film turns into a tedious affair that becomes increasingly benign despite all the heavy themes it tries to tackle.
movie_title: The Lady in the Portrait (Le Portrait interdit) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Thoroughly enjoyable to watch if totally forgettable once you leave the theater, The Commuter feels like one of those films they simply don't make anymore, at least in Hollywood.
Laughs are rather few and far between in this episode, which, at least, has the merit of clocking in at only 92 minutes and flies by quickly enough.
An arresting mediation on construction and destruction.
Seriously, is this the best we can offer adults who don't want to watch Marvel movies?
A clever holiday comedy that just about nails the right mixture of offbeat humor and Yuletide cheer.

This rather clever, breakneck-paced cartoon gives fans exactly what they want: Like the new nemesis voiced by Trey Parker, it shoots mulitple machine-gun bursts of bubblegum at the audience, asking them to chew and enjoy.
The characters are compelling enough to avoid turning into major clichés, while stars Camelia Jordana and Daniel Auteuil prove to be a winning pair.
Rarely, if only in Urgences or classics like Frederick Wiseman's Titticut Follies or John Huston's Let There Be Light, has a filmmaker been able to document madness in such a direct way ...

It's an altogether engrossing crash course in the birth of movies, and if Fremaux makes anything clear in his survey, it's that the Lumieres were not only cinema pioneers - they were perhaps the first auteurs.

An experimental narrative whose transfixing aesthetics compensate for an almost nonexistent story, Evilness (La Maldad) marks a promising if enigmatic feature debut from cinematographer turned director Joshua Gil.

It's a simple, somewhat mundane scenario that, in the hands of a terrific cast and two talented filmmakers, is transformed into a minor Greek comic-tragedy, with one fearless woman trying to stave off loved ones who smother her with guilt and affection.
Its many scenes of decadence are portrayed with all the polish and deliberateness of an Urban Outfitters ad.
Best described as Home Alone meets Michael Haneke's Funny Games, the sadistic horror comedy Safe Neighborhood is the kind of film that's tough to categorize but easy to enjoy.
An absorbing celluloid meditation on geography and history.

National Bird hardly offers any counterpoint to the arguments presented... But it does reveal a program whose international reach and seemingly limitless surveillance powers are extraordinarily difficult to keep in check
A poignant and energetic Brazilian drama that turns a potentially bleak subject into a warmhearted study of genetics, gender and the true meaning of home.
movie_title: Don't Call Me Son (Mãe Só Há Uma) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Nocturama makes an intriguingly cinematic case for showing over telling. But as a depiction of how, and why, terrorists (or anarchists or whatever they are) can take down a city, it falls apart in the face of what happens in the real world.

That's not much of a story to build a film on, but writer-director Rachel Lang and star Salome Richard manage to craft an intriguing feature debut filled with keen observations and slices of dark humor.
A cleverly written, impressively made and incredibly gory tale of one young woman's awakening to the pleasures of the flesh - in all senses of the term.
An intriguing little crime thriller about a struggling young farmer who starts cultivating marijuana, among other cash crops, in order to pay the bills.
A visually striking, atypical portrait of French youth.
The overall effect is still too bland to cause a real stir, and Carion concludes the long voyage pretty much in the way you expect.

Both a behind-the-scenes account of the original production and a feature-length mea culpa for a work that "misrepresented an entire country and group of people," to quote one Turkish expert interviewed early on.
movie_title: Midnight Return: The Story of Billy Hayes and Turkey (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An insightful film school chronicle that will appeal most to those in the know.

Taking their old-school animated style across the Atlantic, directors Alain Gagnol and Jean-Loup Felicioli offer up a heartwarming New York story with Phantom Boy, their second feature collaboration following the 2010 Oscar-nominated A Cat in Paris.

For the most part, Rayhana's ambitious debut remains a fairly gripping account of women finding respite in each other's company at a time, and in a place, where they have few possibilities to express themselves freely.
movie_title: I Still Hide to Smoke (A mon âge je me cache encore pour fumer) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film ultimately works more as a social portrait than as a rather classic bildungsroman, revealing all the sweat, suffering and heartache it takes to build one massive diamond in the rough.

There's a lot in Tour de France that feels either predictable or too on-the-nose, while the loose storyline never manages to hammer home the film's themes of exile, regeneration and what it means to be French.
The assured storytelling and direction, including some of the goriest makeup effects this side of Rob Zombie, turn Raw into the kind of crossover film that takes the horror genre into another domain.
A mysterious minimalist romance.
Sonia Braga shines in this rather classic portrait of a woman who won't let go.
Future '38 can suffer at times from kitsch overkill, even if the playful tone and committed cast makes it a fairly pleasant romp to sit through.
Like The Red Turtle's shipwrecked protagonist, you have to simply stop fighting the current and go with the flow.
It's ultimately hard to tell if the movie is trying to render its subjects with some humanity or otherwise if it's taking advantage of all these poor, beautiful losers.
Lotteau pieces together a comprehensive montage that reveals the Pesmerga's slow but steady advance along the front, in a war that looks to be far from over.
A beautiful dark twisted French fantasy.
Starts off promisingly with its various jibes at upper-class hypocrisy, before fizzling out in a third act that lacks the necessary emotional flair.
movie_title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Employing his usual DIY directorial methods, Gondry seems to be having a blast with all the jerry-rigged objects and antiques provided by production designer Stephane Rozenbaum.
[Cogitore] has a few good ideas and the right elements to set them off, but his bomb doesn't fully detonate.
movie_title: Neither Heaven nor Earth (Ni le ciel ni la terre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A work that showcases the distaff director's raw filmmaking talents but may have to fight its way out of the usual Francophone ghettos.

Despite all the narrative embellishments, the movie does maintain a sense of Reinhardt's persona along with his incredible musical abilities, especially in a trio of concert scenes that highlight each act.
A film that starts off impressively but gradually tires itself out with a loud and loopy caper plot, taking a clever idea to mostly familiar places in the long run.
A rich and strange tale of thwarted sexuality that takes a tad too long to get to the point.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: This modest first feature from Lila Pinell and Chloe Mahieu offers up a tender portrait of a tough world, where budding adolescents come clashing up against the strict regimen of professional athletics.
Hit the Rodin, Jacques.
An intriguing first feature from writer-director Karim Moussaoui that explores the damaged emotional landscape of his homeland.
movie_title: Until the Birds Return (En attendant les hirondelles) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A unique look at a place and people who we have mostly known through news reports or government propaganda, but rarely in movies through such a human point of view.

The acting outside the singing is often on the level of a class play, and the repetition of musical numbers and kitschy dances can grow tiresome to say the least, but you have to give Dumont credit ...
movie_title: Jeannette: The Childhood of Joan of Arc (Jeannette l'enfance de Jeanne d'Arc) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A charming tale of multiple quid pro quos that's as light-hearted as its subject matter is deadly serious.
movie_title: Just to Be Sure (Ôtez-moi d'un doute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are a few intense moments, as well as stabs at humor that border on Coen Bros. territory, but generally speaking the film is a tad too pedestrian in terms of its execution.
[An] eye-opening chronicle of one Burmese monk's long campaign of racism and violence against his country's minority Muslim population.
By remaining deliberately enigmatic, They winds up nearly passing alongside the unique and very special character that lies at its heart.
The film slowly but surely works its charms, painting a rich, emotionally complex portrait of a woman who, like Denis herself, will not let herself be boxed in.
movie_title: Let the Sunshine In (Un beau soleil intérieur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Barbet Schroeder offers up a touching look at unrequited love and neglected memory with the simpatico two-hander, Amnesia.
Fascinating ...
Tomorrow provides a comprehensive look at ways in which activists, organizers and everyday citizens are trying to make the world a better, greener, more sustainable place.
A sharply executed, superbly performed Bulgarian tragic dramedy where the lives of a cosmopolitan PR woman and lonely railroad worker come together in some highly unfortunate ways.
A stark, disquieting portrait of a pair of recovering drug addicts trying to scrape by in the suburban wilderness of Cape Breton Island.
A heavily computer-generated enterprise with more body than brains, more visuals than ideas, as if the original movie's hard drive had been wiped clean of all that was dark, poetic and mystifying.
Easily digestible though very kitschy.
The film is more of a character study than a full-fledged family drama, though one that benefits from strong, naturalistic performances by cast members that seem to know one another all too well.
This one-hour assault on the senses is less about informing the viewer than about jarring them into the realization that we are no less safe now than during the height of the Cold War.
It's intense if somewhat choppy filmmaking, although the passion of the amateur cast and vividness of the Kinshasa locations help make up for the narrative shortcomings.
[A] tough yet loving portrait ...
Provost has once again proven to be a sensitive and sure-handed director of what used to be called "women's films," with this one somewhat of a cross between Douglas Sirk and the Dardennes.

This impeccably shot exposé revisits the world of the original movie while offering up new details, including a series of breathtaking underwater sequences that alone are worth the price of admission.
movie_title: March of the Penguins 2: The Call (L'empereur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This highly conceptual mood piece, which toes the line between documentary and gallery filmmaking, shows a lot more than it tells and never quite connects the dots between anything onscreen.

Canet deserves credit for going to such extremes - even if his conceit runs a bit long - and for taking the satire to the point of no return, rather than offering up the kind of easy reconciliation seen in most movies about the movie business.
Sexist, a bit racist and definitely ridiculous, this high-concept farce does land a few good jokes and is frenetically paced enough to make you forget some of the bad ones.

This beautifully photographed tale of religion, redemption and repressed sensuality can lumber at times due to the heavy-handedness of the scenario, though the many verbal duels between the two leads are also what make it work.
It's a decent concept for any sort of movie - a thriller, a horror flick, a comedy - but the problem here is that writer-director Joe Martin never quite decides which one he wants to make.
[An] informative and somewhat hagiographic documentary ...
This timely Quebecois drama can sometimes creep too far into afterschool special territory, but the intense emotions on display give it a certain raw staying power.

Bedos is known as a public prankster and cultural gadfly, so maybe he and Tillier are simply trying to have some fun. Yet there are moments when they seem to be awfully sincere in their efforts, which makes their film all the more problematic.
The dialogue, delivered as if the kids were rehearsing a class play, feels so unnatural that it's hard to believe anything onscreen, however high the level of fantasy.
Charlie Victor Romeo is rooted in fear and panic, but it's also a deeply empathetic film.
The film works best when it shows Jonathan Daniel Brown's drug kingpin at his most inept and incapable, rather than elevating him to a pothead martyr.
Patrice Leconte struggles to find a coherent rhythm, a problem exacerbated by a hurried running time that compresses some of the novella's more interesting socio-political nuances.
This isn't a film of bedside conversions or radical emotional transformations, nor is it a story about laughing at one's own hardships as a coping mechanism.
The film is clearly wary of either being too saccharine or taking itself--or the notion of compulsive infidelity--too seriously, though its schadenfreude is unwavering.
It pushes itself beyond shrill predictability in its willingness to indict the public and familial histories at its core.
An intriguing feature, but one that ends up dulling your senses with repetitive talking heads and recreated scenarios.
For relying more on emotions than the fascinating knowledge contained in Hawking's mind, The Theory of Everything could've employed more complexity.
Taken as a whole, it's a deeply affecting, incendiary film and the most focused, accomplished biopic in a year of numerous offerings.
Mundruczó's focus is clearly going to the admittedly impressive execution, but White God lacks the narrative weight to leave an impact.
It's all a generally agreeable affair with little impact when all is said and done.
One will never wish to go through precisely what White does, but losing one's parents is inevitable, and the film is a searingly authentic portrait of the process.
Things get weird, and then some, in Patrick Brice's engaging and bizarre comedy.
It may skimp on its characters, but with a mostly successful amalgamation of various tones, Slow West is a beautiful and bold shot in the arm for the genre.
Mississippi Grind provides a venerable acting showcase to a pair of under-appreciated actors, but could have used more impetus in its execution.
The drama's formal elements aren't as compelling as the ideas it wrestles with, but it does make for one of James Franco's more accomplished and complicated performances.
As the finest possible documentary one could get on the subject, Listen to Me Marlon delivers an extraordinarily well-crafted and deeply emotional portrayal.
Directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon with remarkable control, creativity and fervor, the film is equal parts a homage to classic cinema and a heart-wrenching romantic comedy with earned emotion.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As a modern update on Grey Gardens with an added tribute to the love for filmmaking, The Wolfpack is an endlessly fascinating documentary, but it's not quite a great one.
H. simply doesn't feel fully formed, keeping us at a narrative distance from its otherwise relatable characters.
A patiently unfolding drama that displays the lengths one will go to provide shelter and community, and what happens if you step out of bounds.
The most frightening aspect of the documentary is a suggestion that this is only the dawn of what's to come.
A witty, highly entertaining blend of a multitude of genres, one that could truly be great if a bit more compressed.
A brooding, sharp and skillfully crafted, character-focused detective story.
Aside from a few memorable exchanges and effective bursts of violence, The Drop could've use more imagination to distinguish itself from the pack.
While it fails to deliver convincing action and its comedy feels watered down, Central Intelligence does get the "buddy" aspect correct.
The sort of well-meaning, small-scale drama about the creative method that feels too obviously plotted and conventionally scripted to achieve any genuine truths regarding the process.
John Cusack must have used his time-travel powers to wisely foresee sitting out this stale journey into the future.
Saccharine, overwhelmingly melodramatic and filmed with a glossy sheen, one is either quickly won over by the charms of the romantic drama 5 to 7 or simply turned off from the start.
Alex of Venice might not break any new bounds in storytelling but it's a confident exploration of a traumatic life change.
Sony has now fully bought into the narratively-damaging idea that teasing what's to come is more important than the film itself.
In a studio system that so heavily relies on playing all their cards at once, Edwards' restraint is half the fun -- the other half being the fully-satisfying climax.
As a lucid and riveting who-dun-it black comedy, Gone Girl makes for one of Fincher's most purely entertaining films.
Even divorced from scandal, Weiner makes for a captivating, sadly comical look at the machinations of the political process.
Martin has something compelling to say about moving on amidst - or perhaps because of - the humor of life.
Always Shine effectively lingers with a pair of deeply committed performances and Takal's layered dissection of the vulnerabilities inherent in the world of filmmaking.
Thanks to the sensual approach of its cinematography, the result is a warm and formally bold look at what love can mean beyond its initially fantastical promise.
While Don't Think Twice depicts a certain world with incisive specificity, its themes of what success truly means are universal to anyone involved in the arts.
Michôd has created a frighteningly realistic apocalyptic western that's entirely his own.

In an era where much of the spoof genre simply lazy repeats scenarios, [the film] brilliantly and hilariously deconstructs every aspect of the genre to provide one of the funniest films one is bound to see this year.
Laika's technical implementation is exquisite, in what is their most complex undertaking yet.
Despite the contrived drama surrounding it, this is a refreshingly uncynical portrait of familial strife.
The euphoria and anguish of first love has been captured in countless films, but few do it with the level of raw authenticity and intimacy as 6 Years.
The build-up is an intentionally unwieldy one showing the many forms of love, and how the notion of it doesn't always fit in a methodical box, much less a blissful one.
As we dive deeper into the abyss of loss, the story strays from its grounded realism and becomes too contrived to fully convey its intended emotion.
Aptly described by Solondz as Au Hasard Balthazar meets Benji, there's no denying it bears his brand of humor and heartbreak in every scene.
A rapidly entertaining ride through the rise of technology [although] certain sections might feel thematically underdeveloped.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If one imagines a real-life version of Up with a bit of Thelma & Louise thrown in, they get [this] charming on-the-run adventure comedy.
[Lonergan] immaculately constructs a layered, non-linear exploration of the ripple effects of loss and grief.
As a document of this incomprehensible grief, Newtown works poignantly well.
Goat is a compelling watch, but in the end, its themes are a bit muddled, and certainly not unique.
[Rebecca] Hall, in one of her best performances, embodies Christine with searing intensity.
An acutely funny testament to single parenting and the specific bond it fosters when both sides put in their all.
Perhaps the purest distillation of [Kelly Reichardt's] sensibilities as she patiently explores the longing for human connection in a world where men too often get prioritized.
While the structure can be a touch too formulaic, it's difficult to resist getting swept up in the music and its modest ambitions.
Joshy doesn't provide any new revelations about the transition into adulthood, but, with an amusing ensemble, you could be stuck with a much worse group of guys.
What's lacking in aesthetic cohesion, pacing, and subtlety is made up for in a powerful lead performance and an essential story with compelling religious undercurrents.
In a news cycle which can often make our leaders seem like impassive mouthpieces, Southside With You exceeds in humanizing them.
As if Ingmar Bergman and Ken Russell co-directed Kill List ... it's a delightfully insane bit of 17th century devilish fun.
An exhausting, grating experience, lacking in wit and cleverness as it crumbles underneath its wall-to-wall torrent of jokes.
War Story provides a refreshingly specific, restrained story of loss and recovery in the boundaries of battle.
Schamus wrings out the vigorous dialogue by letting a standard plot fall by the wayside and have the film luxuriate in a number of spectacularly heated conversations.
A muscular, passable piece of slick entertainment on the action front, The Gunman's ambitions are welcome, but could have used another polish.
Despite actors who are clearly committed to the material, The Free World is an unfortunate misfire of banality.
An effective crowd-pleaser, even if it doesn't saying anything remarkably new about finding one's identity.
There's a richness to the cinematography that, along with the central performance, hearkens back to a character study from a few decades prior.
While not all of these work cohesively, Monahan's particular rhythm of language makes Mojave a bizarrely compelling watch.
The emotionally dark drama favors a brooding mood and character-centered relationships over jump scares and gore-filled action.
This is a drama, despite feeling rushed in sections, intent on providing satisfaction above all else.
A slick, but dated and hollow jaunt through the ripple effects of over-reaching technology and the questions of morality that accompany such power.
Delighting with inventive setpieces and an affable lead in Paul Rudd, Ant-Man is eccentric enough to amuse, but can often feel watered-down in execution.
Part awe-inspiring nature documentary, part personal reflective journey, Meru gives equal weight to both of these sides of the coin.
An inventive, wild piece of filmmaking that one will either be sold on by the premise or turn away quickly.
Blends psychological-thriller elements with unexpected humor for a thoroughly unsettling plunge into a nightmare of fear and intolerance.
Rodrigo García's beautiful, spare drama can frustrate as much as it allures with meditations on finding meaning in one's life (and beyond).
A rollicking space procedural that depends on some logic, and a great deal of luck.
With an overriding penchant for nobility above all, Bridge of Spies has a welcome straightforward charm despite its ultimately understated impact.
Perhaps its most significant achievement is its ability to make one greater appreciate every sense the world has for us to experience.
Despite the amount of delectably photographed dishes, the drama in Burnt unfortunately feels undercooked and watered down.
A fairly muddled entry into the Bond canon.
An immaculately lensed, large-scale, and defiantly heartless endurance test.
American Ultra may surprise some with its emotional core, but it's ultimately little more than a lazy Tarantino knock-off.
It may have more brains behind it than The Ruins, but hopefully Smith can find material truly worthy of his technical talents with his next feature.
Aisholpan offers a real-life, profoundly inspiring testament to disregard age-old societal constraints and forge ahead with your passion.
Araki's latest drama is a refreshingly frank coming-of-age story, featuring another great performance from Woodley.
This a tentpole that recognizes once you hit the start button, you're hoping for a mindless, entertaining time, and, in the end, you won't feel like you wasted one of your lives.
An early-established folkloric weight and timelessness runs throughout Dominik's neo-western masterpiece.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Functions more as a roller coaster ride of frights and humor than a dread-inducing exercise in terror.
Much of the two-plus hours finds Reeves feigning character development with drawn-out close-ups that register as little more than an ostentatious showcase for the peerless visual effects.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's a momentum to Rough Night that is pleasing enough, but the bar for comedy should be set higher, and this cliché-filled outing never quite clears it.
The details in this post-apocalyptic chamber drama - flat-out horror this is not - are spare, an initially refreshing decision that ultimately results in a rather empty, half-formed narrative.
When everything is done with a wink, it's not a surprise to have a reaction that comes down to a shrug.
Despite a layer of derivative blandness, there's something downright invigorating about a film without loftier ambitions than providing slasher-in-space pulp.
There's an emotional detachment at its core that renders it an innocuously serviceable live-action remake.
A hyper-focused, dream-like portrait of a teenager grappling with both the conditions of his upbringing and a newfound identity.
Considering how Perry intricately carves out the understated instincts of each of these characters, it's easily his most humane and emotionally complex film.
An impeccably composed drama of quiet humanity and curiosity.
An observant, but not entirely successful outcry for the agency of the under-represented.
While watching Room, if one wished there was more laughs to go with the trauma, Brigsby Bear is the film you've been looking for.
Much of this drama feels mechanized for blunt audience reaction, rather than settling us into a world we can care about with stakes that render authentic.
The Commuter further proves Collet-Serra is a master at cleanly setting the dominoes in confined environments and thrillingly controlling their fall.

[Panos] Cosmatos' vision is an all-encompassing of pure psychosis. By easing us into this world through Red and Mandy's touching and unconventional romance, it makes the pay-off to come that much greater.
With every new moment of restrained poeticism, it's astounding this is a director's first time behind the camera.
[Bo] Burnham's comedy has always been adept at exploring human insecurities, so it's no surprise he zeroes in on the overwhelming emotional vulnerability that afflicts young teens.
While the film feels overly familiar in plot, it's lightweight, pleasurable tone causes it to glide by.

A shimmering example of what Hollywood sci-fi can achieve when the aim is high, Annihilation is a gripping, mystifying adventure and proof that a transportive experience is more rewarding than a story with clean-cut resolutions.
While Red Sparrow ultimately doesn't earn its all-consuming, grueling dourness, there are a few thrills to be had.
Sorry to Bother You will surely strike a chord with any viewer, even if it doesn't fully cohere.
Like a lucid nightmare where no one can feel your alienation no matter how loud you scream out.
With its methodically tidy structure and a script that, beat for beat, lays the pieces to be a quintessential crowd-pleaser, Puzzle fits together like a perfect, well... you know.

Not containing the wit to be smart, thrilling sci-fi nor the chutzpah to embrace a fun, B-movie shlock vibe, it unfortunately feels like an uninspired TV pilot that any other network would've permanently locked in a vault.
One imagines if Wilson saw this film, he'd chastise it for being too plainly amiable and quickly move on to his next target.
A drama of boundless spontaneity as Decker deftly examines mental illness and the potentially exploitative lines a performer may cross when pulling life into art.
While it doesn't land with as much impact as it should, the contradictory, heart-numbing effects of such a dehabiliting program are conveyed with a keen sense of nuance by Akhavan.

David and Nathan Zellner have crafted an anti-western, lovingly poking fun at its foundation while slyly pulling the rug under the audience in humorous, forward-thinking, and genre-redefining fashion.
By trying to do everything, it feels like nothing is accomplished.
The Tale is a soul-excavating reckoning with the suppression of trauma and a testament to the courage required for a victim to confront the most damaging moments of their lives.
[Skate Kitchen] is such a step-up in vibrancy, scope, and emotion that it feels like the introduction of an entirely different, more accomplished filmmaker.
John Callahan's life is a fascinatingly complex one, and Phoenix is certainly the ideal actor to portray him, but Gus Van Sant's maudlin, erratic approach leaves too little of an impression.
movie_title: Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A generous, graceful, full-hearted drama about the complexities of desiring a child when your physiology denies you at every turn.
Hereditary burrows deep in the brain, waiting to scare you again the next time you turn the lights off or sit down for a family meal.
Filled with scenes both broad and understated, Mudbound may take some time to find an engaging rhythm and poignant depth, but once it does, the powerful last act will not be soon forgotten.
On paper, it's among the most inessential blockbusters of the year, but Spider-Man: Homecoming proves that going back to square one and adding good-hearted altruism can go a long way.
L.A. Times stands apart with striking style in its self-aware shallowness.
Despite an ending that is far too obvious and tidy, Agnus Dei is a moving drama about the struggle to keep one's faith in the most difficult of situations.
Free State of Jones has a story worth telling, it just doesn't know how to effectively do so.
If only this set of memorable characters were serving a story that didn't feel half-rate.
Ida is a quaint drama in technique, but its formidable power lies in these cardinal quandaries.
Fishing Without Nets provides a thorough examination at the motives of those involved, particularly the group's internal conflicts.
Abrahamson eventually tells us the answers, but he's far more interested in dissecting the intricacies and dynamic of a band along the way.
The Better Angels makes for a sublime, transfixing, and informative look at the early life of Abraham Lincoln.
Ghostbusters has a persistent dose of rollicking, scrappy fun that the ideal summer blockbuster should contain -- all the way past the last credits.
Land Ho!'s success is found in its small observations and flawless, off-beat leads.
As their entire mission rests on the most minuscule of actions, Corbijn has crafted a smart, slow-burn thriller.
While the unforeseen places it goes kept me engaged, unearned character motivations, and an awkward genre balance prevent this from being a knock-out exploitation noir entry.
What We Do in the Shadows is proof that the vampire genre is alive and well as long as it's in the right hands.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Abbasi and co-writer Steven Reneau nail the socio-economic factors in this life of crime.
Those that are on-board with its distressing comedy will find both an acute exploration of mental illness and the makings of a cult classic.
Life After Beth remains a mildly funny film in search of a director with some bite.
Alex Ross Perry certainly offers a nod to a handful of directors, but has crafted something wholly his own with Listen Up Philip.
With a commonplace technical approach, The Skeleton Twins could have used a more turbulent hand behind the camera to accompany the ups and downs of our lead arcs.
In a career fixated on the machinations of filmmaking presented through both a carnal and political eye, Brian De Palma's fascinations converged idyllically with Blow Out.
Laggies soon goes off the rails, its plot becoming more contrived and characters increasingly erratic.
As Sausage Party breaks out of its Pixar-inspired packaging, so to speak, its repetitiveness evolves into a delirious cacophony of obscenities.
Pete's Dragon has an emotional sensitivity, aesthetic clarity, and all-around sense of fun that creates what feels like an unearned miracle in the current summer tentpole season.
The director is keen in making sure the film's various backstories converge in dramatically poignant fashion.
Far from achieving the holy grail of comedy.
One of the most original, narratively audacious films I've ever seen.
In his directorial debut, Matt Spicer gets right what so many other films commenting on today's technology obsession fail to capture.
Sheridan's distinct artistry of dialogue is sorely missing.
The harrowing drama Berlin Syndrome makes room for nuance and depth.
Fascinatingly explores the perception and dissolution of what we remember throughout our lives.
For an hour-and-a-half, Robespierre opened her heart and showed the tenderness that a life in disarray can bring, and I'm grateful to have the opportunity to witness it.
Works as both a rare introduction to a way of life largely unseen as well as a touching depiction of fighting for what's most important in life.
On paper, the plot of Assassin's Creed is insanely goofy, but you'd never know it when executed with this much self-importance.
The strangest thing about [Marvel's] latest feature is that all of these characters come across utterly bored with their vocations.
Everything Roberts wants to convey is obtrusively front and center, leaving little room for the viewer to have any interpretation for themselves.
Buster's Mal Heart loses confidence as it proceeds, resulting in a journey of half-formed ideas that could've used as much focus as Malek's dead-eyed glance.
Cianfrance has a proven track record of exploring how guilt can transform when burdened by the weight of time, but it's never felt more artificial in his hands.
A feat of accentuated sound design and arresting cinematography, luxuriating in the beauty of Italy.
A fantastical adventure with innovation and awe at every turn, despite a story that could benefit from having more specificity and focus.
Gui Zi's unassuming, unpretentious script rolls along nicely, but it's Bensham and Jie who, along with the supporting cast, really raise the bar here.

When placed in its cultural context and presented as a reawakening of spirit in youngish widow ... belly dancing becomes not a cringe-worthy, faux-authentic gimmick but much more an expression of personal freedom and passion.
Reinforces the often forgotten fact of the world's remarkably varying human population and mindset, and its capacity to heal using creative, natural and ancient antidotes.
Charles' entertaining film chronicles Seinfeld's return to stand-up comedy after the wrap of his legendary sitcom, alongside wannabe comic Adams' attempts to get his shot at the big time.
Thoughtful, intelligent film.
As with most porn, viewing this smut for over an hour straight is not the most exciting way to spend one's time.
It's the included portions of Deren's films that are the best part of In the Mirror of Maya Deren.
movie_title: In the Mirror of Maya Deren (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Akerman spends so much time capturing non-events, albeit picturesquely, she misses out on the opportunity to delve deeper into the plights of the people themselves.
movie_title: From the Other Side (De L'autre Cote) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As beautiful as it often is to watch, Coral Reef Adventure ultimately comes off as a bit too kid-friendly and faux-inspirational, which is kind of a drag.
Oddly nostalgic.
movie_title: Hell's Highway: The True Story of Highway Safety Films (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The 3D images only enhance the film's otherworldly quality, giving it a strange combo of you-are-there closeness with the disorienting unreality of the seemingly broken-down fourth wall of the movie screen.
Unsettling.
It's always disappointing when a documentary fails to live up to -- or offer any new insight into -- its chosen topic. Unfortunately, that's precisely what Arthur Dong's Family Fundamentals does.

[Lin Chung's] voice is rather unexceptional, even irritating (at least to this Western ear), making it awfully hard to buy the impetus for the complicated love triangle that develops between the three central characters.
When a karaoke film's blast-from-the-past cameo stands out as its most memorable aspect, the problems shriek that much louder.
Pleasing documentary.
... a confusing drudgery.
Anderson's and Mo'Nique's talents make Two Can Play That Game just amusing and light enough to be worth the trouble despite its often trite familiarity.
A mildly engrossing tale of devotion and loss, but one that passes up the chance to match the impassioned level to which its soundtrack rises.
Smith should take a lesson from Silent Bob: sometimes less is more.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A low-cal account of artistic endeavor and sacrifice.
All three actors combine to help make Colin Nutley's bizarre love triangle an engrossing one.
Suffers from a rambling, allegory-laden storyline that makes it nearly impossible to follow.
A tellingly discouraging testament to the inherently complicated and manipulative workings of a formerly subjugated culture not fully freed from its oppressors.
Our Song has an admirably raw, unkempt air about it, as do its performances.
It's incessantly verbose, so stuffed with explanation and exposition it's as if Ryan finds the idea of even the most basic visual expression unwarranted.
movie_title: The Young Girl and the Monsoon (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Rampling carries Under the Sand with her assured turn as the dolefully loyal Marie.
Soderbergh deftly weaves together four stories depicting the causes and effects of the illegal drug trade.
Has a refreshingly simple look and feel; shots are not intricately choreographed, and there are no perfectly placed musical cues to garishly indicate where a laugh, cry or gasp is requested.

Winds up being both revelatory and narcissistic, achieving some honest insight into relationships that most high-concept films candy-coat with pat storylines, precious circumstances and beautiful stars.
Lightheartedness is one thing, but trivializing cheating while failing to do so with humor or creativity makes for an unsuccessful if not unseemly film.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Bed (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Offers considerably more insight into the conceptions of real and artificial intelligence and emotion than the immensely overrated debacle that is AI: Artificial Intelligence.
An interesting doc, if only because it serves to introduce the work of a gifted, unique artist to those of us who have found little good to say about the 1980s and the excesses they produced.
By merely capturing the seemingly simple images of work and play, human and synthetic, Palfi constantly juxtaposes the natural and industrial realms to startling effect.

Hollywoodland works best -- as a cold look at the entertainment industry's obsession with youth and the fatality brought on by an errant wrinkle or gray hair, impressively encapsulated by Diane Lane's strong showing as the past-her-prime.
Clerks II would make for an appropriate end to Smith's lackluster career.

Keating, who has shot for the Maysles brothers and Barbara Kopple, amasses an impressive amount of evidence to bolster his claims, allowing the relative dryness of his style to be overshadowed by the revelatory nature of his research.

Rae borrows a bit heavily from the Oliver Stone school of filmmaking: Quick cuts of seemingly random footage do more to draw attention to a possible dearth of relevant background materials than to evoke ideas of Native American history and struggle.

Full of weak whimsy, woefully unsuccessful tries at humor and awkwardness from first scene to last, Casanova must have been a disaster from the script stage, and Hallstrom's unsteady decisions only speed up the free fall.
A message film delivered with subtlety and grace, not allowing its weighty subject matter to overshadow the quiet dignity of its characters.

Games of Love and Chance plays like a French version of Jim McKay's Our Song. But, unlike McKay's superior American version, Kechiche is unable to transform the everyday lives of his characters into something meaningful.
Well-crafted and sufficiently disturbing.
Bitton slyly layers numerous interviews with locals atop the visuals, infusing each scene with an unexpectedly potent context.
[A] memorable portrait of one man's immeasurable passion for preservation.
The film presents its lofty goals as transparently as its publicity materials, its clunky dialogue and diminished production value adding to its inordinate lack of sophistication.
A tepid startle-fest, with fairly run-of-the-mill scares that leave no lasting impression.

Browne's film succeeds on numerous levels, in no small part because he admirably balances the slow-pitch, flyover-state silliness of bowling with a genuine appreciation of the inherent tensions and rivalries in a professional spectator sport.
Double Dare remains an entertaining and informative look at a little-known struggle for equality and respect in a physically unforgiving but completely vital Hollywood discipline.
The missed opportunities are impossible to ignore.
movie_title: Three of Hearts: A Postmodern Family (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A film with remarkably little to recommend it.
[Loach] sheds little new light on the inevitable clashes between parents rooted to their native culture and their Western-influenced offspring.

A poor script, occasionally baffling editing, and actors who cannot rise above the various missteps combine to make A Silent Love a messy, confusing debut that more resembles a student film than a theatrical release.
No doubt it's a strong case. Why, then, does it feel so unconstructive?
Kampmeier reveals her inexperience as a feature filmmaker, and her effort struggles with the weight of its own subject matter and final ambiguities.
The overtly cerebral, surreal motifs of Gozu distract from Miike's potent -- and seriously twisted -- analyses of women and sex.
Aside from a few brief glimmers of hope or happiness, director Barbara Albert piles her compilation of abject misery a bit too high.
The courage, curiosity and perhaps partial insanity of the explorers -- not to mention the film crew -- are admirable, as their trials and tribulations yield stunning images galore.

The film's indisputable overall message is chilling no matter what side of the debate you're on: Some innocent men almost died for crimes for which they were wrongly convicted, so maybe some other innocent men actually did die.
The final product feels frustratingly incomplete.
Fails to ignite much emotion.
A humdrum coming-of-age piece.
Largely a documentary filmmaker, Masud may need a few more features under his belt before his work has a consistent flow.
Marathon contains nothing more than its thin premise.
As an action movie, SPECTRE does zip along initially until the halfway mark when the mythology and the intentional nostalgia trip pull on the handbrake.

Avoid this film at all costs. If you later find that any of your friends or family actually liked this movie, then we suggest you disassociate yourself from them, and avoid them at all costs too, as they will only disappoint you somewhere down the line.
The screenplay plays like a character study of the most obvious.
Not just providing a one-note take on an enigmatic person, it captures unexpected layers that we never would have thought existed.
An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power is an important and relevant worldwide look at the environmental crisis.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The missteps seem to never end as the director and actors struggle to bring some kind of coherence to this unwieldy film.
This well-directed, serviceable yarn proves the importance of casting - especially when we're spending nearly two hours with just two actors.
Emma Stone is the standout, bringing an astounding power and depth to her role as she layers the complexities of King.
A thinly-sketched culture clash that misses the romanticism of its source material.
